Slime Rancher is a delightful and enchanting adventure that invites players into the colorful world of the Far, Far Range. Capturing and ranching adorable slimes while exploring the diverse environments is a captivating experience. The game's laid-back atmosphere and charming aesthetic make it a perfect escape from the hustle and bustle of daily life. The progression system, from basic ranching to exploring hidden areas, offers a sense of accomplishment and discovery. With its engaging gameplay, charming characters, and a world filled with slimes of all shapes and sizes, Slime Rancher is a heartwarming journey that will leave you smiling from ear to ear.

[i]Slime Rancher[/i] has been the best farm game experience I’ve had sense the early days of [i]FarmVille[/i]. Which apparently was 15 years ago now…. ahhhhh! Anyway, back to [i]Slime Rancher[/i], I was absolutely infatuated with this game from the moment I booted it up until the last achievement popped. I found it was extremely hard to put down as there was always one more thing I needed to do. Simply put, it’s everything you would want from a farming game. The player is presented with a plethora of options when it comes to which vegetation they would like to grow; and which slimes they wish to corral. It’s not the biggest game out there but it’s a good balance of quality over quantity. As if it was longer, I fear grinding would sap the fun out of it. My only recommendation for this game would be to pay attention to the story line, as it will pleasantly surprise you. I was mindlessly playing through this game without reading anything. I definitely missed out there, as getting to experience this surprisingly deep & meaningful tale firsthand will always be better than learning it from a lore video.

The end of the story made me cry because I was going through something similar at the time.

This game truly reminds me of easier times and really exemplifies "Don't cry because its over. Smile because it happened".

It's relaxing and therapeutic even. (cheaper than therapy and achieves the same effect)

-Slimes: Cute

This game is very fun and relaxing, if you know how to play it. First off, the water tank is not an option, YOU HAVE TO BUY IT, if you don't buy you will be completely destroyed by the Tarrs. Second, do not over fill your corrals, your slimes will escape, to prevent this either chill out on the slimes, or buy upgrades such as tall walls, or the sky shield. Lastly, unless you know what you are doing, DO NOT MIX SLIME TYPES!!!! The slimes will first become big slimes, which will, if you are not careful, will escape, and or become Tarrs, and eat your entire ranch. If Tarrs do spawn, use the water attachment on your arm thing to destroy them. Do recommend tho

Cute, but tedious.

Gameplay loop is torn between either being jailed to your seven plots in your ranch or you explore the mundane same-y world. Being stuck in your farm is much more profitable but maddening.
If you constantly explore, it can get quite boring after a few hours - and the exploration isn't really worth it?

Character's aren't interesting since you only talk to screens. Gameplay loop is wonderful for the early game (like first 5 hours). Missions are a chore and have pisspoor rewards. This game is not that challenging, nor it has that rewarding midgame or endgame depth and consistency. Everything feels shallow and repetitive. You're not really being given a reason to "work", it's that you're bored and have nothing to do, so you painstakingly give yourself mundane shallow tasks to keep you occupied, because the game's foundations are not that thought out.

I will not try out the sequel, it looks the same and I have no trust they're going to fix the problems found in this game.

Initially I picked "Yes" and started writing a review. But as I wrote, I realized that this game isn't actually very good. It's cute, but ultimately pointless and tedious.

You build a slime ranch with gardens, chickens, and a bunch of different slimes, but no one ever stops to tell you why you're doing this. Make a bunch of money, but again there's no real reason to do that. There's no storyline except some messages dotting the land from the guy who owned the farm before you, but his story doesn't serve any real purpose, either. You get some emails, but they're barely worth reading.

So you go out and explore because there are places to go, and you find new slimes and things to take home, but there's never any point to any of it except that it's there to do. I don't need some grand story or much to go on, really, but I just kept waiting for some sort of thing to happen and it never did. If "Slime Ranching" is what you want to do, you can amass enough slimes from just outside your farm to create an incredibly lucrative farm.

Also, upgrades to your farm and your equipment seem to appear at predetermined times, so there's not even that to look forward to because there's no way to know if you're going to get a useful new upgrade or just another bit of HP that you don't need because this game is clearly for children and nothing will challenge your health at all.

And the backtracking around the map is insufferable after a while.

Very cute and squishy. There's adventure, exploration, cute slime's and some not so cute slime's. Overall, it's a great sandbox game that gives you enough plot to stay interested in the game's story while what you're really doing is farming slime poop that looks like sparkly gems. Definitely recommend.

Slime Rancher is an incredibly chill, cute and fun game I'm very passionate about. This game has never failed to cheer me up when I'm feeling down, its a fun experience for anyone interested in ranching, and slimes. go figure. i recommend to anyone looking for a fun game, an adorable story, a peaceful soundtrack and really gorgeous, simplistic visuals.

the characters are fun and the designs are great, i love the personality and dynamics each character has. The story is awesome, its very cute and its fun to go through it as you explore the Far, Far Range. Last but not least, the stars of the show, the slimes! the designs are so good. each slime combination is very different from the last, and they all have their pros and cons, which i love. its also fun to go through each and every combination there is, and the environments you have to travel through to find each different slime are all really beautiful and full of life. 

in short, I love this game. there's a lot i haven't mentioned here but i think its worth buying the game and exploring for yourself. or, if you'd rather stay up to date, Slime Rancher 2 was released recently, and that's a blast too. (you don't have to play 1 to understand 2, but i recommend it, you'd miss out on a lot of story otherwise!)

As if the gods themselves dipped their brushes in rainbow dew, the world of Slime Rancher unfolds before you. Slimes, plump and mischievous, bounce like lost souls seeking redemption. Their eyes, wide as the abyss, hold secrets and dreams. The grass sways, whispering forgotten hymns to the wind. Truly, it is a sight to behold, worthy of a thousand sunrises.

Picture this, brave Ashen One: You, clad in your VacPack armor, venturing into the wilds to capture these gelatinous marvels. Each slime, a tiny universe of quirks and desires. Some crave fruit, others crave meat, and a few harbor secrets that could unravel the very fabric of reality. Forge bonds with them, feed them, and witness their metamorphosis. It’s like kindling a bonfire in your heart.

Hidden caves, ancient ruins, and mysterious artifacts await your curious gaze. The Far Far Range is a tapestry of whimsy, stitched together by cosmic threads. Seek out the elusive Gilded Ginger, a delicacy coveted by slimes and gods alike. Unravel the enigma of ancient statues, their eyes following your every move. And when the sun sets, watch the phosphorescent slimes dance, their glow echoing forgotten prophecies.

Like shards of Estus, upgrades beckon you. Expand your ranch, build silos, and unlock gadgets that defy reason. Jetpacks, teleporters, and music boxes – all at your disposal. Customize your home, paint it with memories, and let the echoes of your deeds resonate through the ages. For every plort you sell, a piece of your legacy unfurls.
DREAM GAME OF EVERY KID IN 2016

Game Play 1.5/2
Slime Rancher has a tycoon style game play where you can explore the world while your farm semi passively generates income, and your exploration efforts + farm optimization directly correlate with the amount of money you make. It's a fun game play loop, with good risk and reward. For example, you can house many slimes on your farm, but the more mouths you have to feed the harder it is to manage them. Or you could place two different types of largo slimes right next to each other for compactness, but it risks them turning into tarr. There are also optional challenges you can perform that will grant you extra rewards and more space to put slimes. 
Not one person's farm will look the same, especially with all the decoration you can place around. However, decoration isn't easy to come by, and the main game play loop is held back by two things. Players that enjoy exploring will find it difficult to make money since they're not tending to the slimes at the farm, and you need money to buy personal upgrades that make exploring easier. Players that enjoy farming will not be able to access the rarer slimes in hard to reach parts of the world. For some this sounds like a good thing, requiring players to perform both tasks for the full experience. But it is impossible to multitask between these two, unless there was some sort of drone that could assist players by automating tasks. 
If you unlock the lab and interact with the refinery, the game gains an additional layer of factory style game play. Drones are the primary gizmo that players want to focus on, being able to perform simple tasks in the player's stead. However for the game to not immediately break after getting drones, you must water them occasionally to keep them going. I tried figuring out how to automatically water the drones, but it's not possible. They are still useful, but there was a missed opportunity. The gizmos do not add enough depth for players that enjoy optimizing automation, and for players that just want to farm, they completely remove any motivation or reason to do so. Making money becomes as simple as going to sleep, watering your drones, and repeating. So I believe that Slime Rancher's strongest game play comes from the mid game, when you're discovering new slimes and buying new upgrades. 

Story 1.3/2 
Slime Rancher's story all comes from emails, notes left behind a previous rancher, and interacting with the characters that give you special missions. All of the story is completely optional (except for Casey's emails) and well paced. It also encourages more exploration, and I believe has a good moral. My only critique is that some of the characters are one note, and the agency you have to affect the story boils down to "you either do the story or you don't." 

Graphics 1.4/2
This game has a 3D cartoony art style which completely fits the game's tone, and the slimes all look adorable. However, because of how often textures get reused in the game, some of the areas start to look samey. You can only really tell the difference if you know the area's geometry. The lighting isn't bad either, but nothing revolutionary. At least I didn't encounter any visual bugs.

Music 2/2
This soundtrack is beautiful, and widely varied. It gives the vibes of driving a pickup truck down a long lonely road, which matches the game's lonely yet adventurous tone. I have this game's songs in my Spotify play lists, and I feel nostalgic when I listen to them. My favorite song is Ancient Ruins because it perfectly encapsulates the mystery of the world, it feels like I only just started playing the game after unlocking the area. 

Price 1/2
For $20, this game is just right. However the play time can be quite short depending on your engagement with the game, and I feel it has hardly any replay ability, even with the rush mode. I also bought the secret style pack DLC for $8. It just adds variant skins for the slimes, something a mod could've done. It's more something you would buy if you wanted to support the developers.

[h1] Why you should or should not play Slime Rancher [/h1]

[b] What is Slime Rancher? [/b]

I have been playing this game for a few years now, even though the hours don't have to show for it. This is a adorable game about a person who enjoys exploring and have come to a planet that seems to have a load of friendly little slime creatures. They are the smaller slimes, which have individual names and then there are the bigger slimes which are two slimes combined together which are called "largos" and then the biggest slimes which are called "Gordos". You can capture slimes and put them into pens to collect their plorts (poo) and sell it for money. You can also grow and harvest crops as well as farm chickens. You have to be careful though because something called tar can spawn and reek havoc on your world.

[b] Initial Thoughts: [/b]

-"This game is adorable."
-"Honey slimes are my favourite." 
-"HONEY LARGO CULT HONEY LARGO CULT HONEY LARGO CULT."

(No honey largos or slimes were hurt in the game or the making of this comment)

[b] Beginner Player Friendly?  [/b]

This game isn't to complicated. It can be a little confusing at first and the puzzles that are in the game can be a little confusing however its nothing to hard to figure out. So I would say this game is beginner player friendly. The key binds are super simple as well and it is controller compatible. 

[b] Game Play: [/b]

The game play itself is very entertaining. You get to be in first person. The game is not multiplayer but honestly I think this game would be so cool with a multiplayer mode. This game does have a story, though you could go through and play the whole game without the story itself. (it wont impact your decisions or any of your game play if you do not acknowledge the story.) There is a few different game modes 
though, there are a few other 'speed run' game modes which can help out with a challenge to get as much money as possible in a short period of time. You have a lot of upgrades which you can do for the objects, the pens and the farms. You can also use items to upgrade your worlds and make tools.

There is a VR mode for anyone who is interested in that. I have not played much of it but its so so cute. 

[b] Graphics: [/b]

The graphics are simple and cartoon like. I don't think they could have done better with these graphics as it matches their game very well. The slimes also react and interact very well with the environment around them. It makes the game feel more life like in a way. However life like slimes with smiley faces can be. I feel like they could have done a little more with whatever is happening beyond the water and sea, but its not important to the game. This game can run on very low end computers. It also is available on console for those of you who would rather play from the comfort of your own bed. 

[b] Community: [/b]

The community for this game is very friendly so do not be afraid to ask questions about anything you may be struggling with. 

[b] How long can you play? [/b]

This game's story will take upwards to hours. If you are a speed runner you could probably finish most if not all of it within 2 hours. You can realistically play this for as long as you want, but for me once I have finished pretty much everything it was game over. 

[b] My Opinion: [/b]

I think this game is a really fun and cute comfy cosy game for anyone looking for a relaxing good time. The objectives are simple and you don't have to think too too much (which sometimes is what we need) 

[i] Any major edits that are made with this review will be added here: [/i]

Slime Rancher is an excellent experience for new players to manager style games as well as veterans looking for a new spin on things. The base game can be split into 3 main stages, 1). Exploration 2). Expansion 3). Automation.

Stage 1). Exploration: When starting a new slime rancher playthrough the player will be given a very basic tutorial via pop up prompts instructing the player on how to move and use the basic abilities of the character. (The player is not required to complete this tutorial before venturing out into the world beyond the safety of the ranch.) Once the player has completed all tutorial tasks they are encouraged to explore the world to collect resources and Slimes to bring back to the ranch and begin the core of the game. Slimes can be corralled and fed to produce “plort” which can be sold for profit at the market allowing the player to upgrade themselves and the ranch to further increase financial gain. During this time the player is at very minimal risk as they only have access to one area of the map and 3 types of slimes with a fourth only being available during the night cycle. While this initial phase of the game is magical during a first time run of the game it can be tedious for future playthroughs as there is little that can be done to expedite early progression.

Stage 2). Expansion: At this point in the game the player has unlocked new regions of the map, new slimes breeds, new areas of the ranch and has experimented with hybrid slime breeds or “Largos” as the game refers to them. It is during this stage of the game in which the player faces the greatest amount of danger as they encounter new more dangerous and profitable slime breeds as well as more treacherous terrain. While experimenting with Largos the player will also likely encounter “Tarr” which are a breed of slimes that produce no plort, consume other nearby slimes and actively seek out and attack the player. Tarr are created if a hybrid slime is crossed with a third breed of slime and pose an immediate threat to both the player’s health and profit. This stage of the game will take up a majority of any given playthrough and will also demand the most of a player in terms of managing the ranch forcing the player to do less and less exploring.

Stage 3). Automation: The ultimate goal of any good management game is to make a factory that completes objectives for you and slime rancher does not miss this mark. After unlocking the laboratory section of the ranch, he is introduced to “Slime Science” giving the player an entirely new way to interact with the world. Specifically the drone gadget gives the player a great deal of freedom to explore the world and find hidden secrets as it can be programmed to do all rancher tasks and only needs an occasional refueling. This reopening of the world is great but it suffers from the fact that most of the exploration type players will have already been burnt out by the management phase of the game.

Stage 4). Postgame and Extras: While there are 3 main stages of the game there is also an entire set of extra areas that are completely unrelated to the main world map and story. The player can enter these areas the moment they unlock the corresponding sections of the ranch but since the gameplay of these areas is so wildly different from the base game and the needs of the ranch do still occur while you are in these areas it’s highly recommended you wait until you have some automation before going to these areas. The extra sections of the map, while a fun break from the standard gameplay loop, really offer very little other than an extension to the ranch and a minigame. Only one of the three bonus areas actually introduces a new type of slime that you can bring to the ranch and even then you can only bring back hybrids so if you are a collector type player you won’t actually be able to display the new slime type.

Overall Slime Rancher is a great game that I highly recommend to both explorer and manager players with only minor setbacks to fun in the second half of the game.

This is a very good idle game, here are a few things I like about it

- Even though it has a sprint button, it's not like some games with a sprint button where whenever you're walking it feels painful
- The art style is very unique and just radiates positivity
- It feels like upgrading your stuff is improving your life, unlike some idle games where it'll feel like you're just doing things because what else is there to do

- I personally wouldn't say it's worth 20$ because I don't think I'm gonna put a ton of time into this game, but if you're the kind of person who can grind out idle games for hours on end, I'd definitely say it's worth the price

Unlike other farming simulation games that engage players with goal-oriented progression, intricate mechanics, or captivating worlds to explore, Slime Rancher deviates from these conventions. The gameplay primarily revolves around simple tasks: collecting slimes, feeding them, and harvesting their poo for sale. It sounds absurd, right? That's because it is. The earned currency allows players to unlock minor quality-of-life upgrades, such as autofeeders, collectors, teleporters, and purely cosmetic items, all aimed at facilitating the continuous cycle of slime collection and poo selling. There was a real missed opportunity to introduce complexity in the slime management aspect of the game, through management of their personalities and behaviours, but each of the slimes act in the same manner: jumping, attacking, hungry. 

The game's narrative, or lack thereof, is delivered through poorly written emails and scattered notes throughout the world. Progression is hindered by locked biomes, requiring players to feed large slimes significant amounts of veggies, fruit, or meat to obtain keys to unlock doors—an unnecessary impediment to advancement. The additional biomes lack substantial visual variety, typically differing only in color palette and vegetation.

Navigating the environment proves cumbersome, with the game introducing significant verticality. While an upgradeable jetpack is meant to aid movement, its power is limited and feels as though it's powered by slime farts. Players will find themselves expending a substantial portion of energy just to hover a few feet above the ground, creating frustration rather than assistance.

Ultimately, Slime Rancher offers a grinding experience with little payoff. The cycle of collecting slimes and selling resources persists without significant narrative or gameplay advancements, leaving players with the ongoing prospect of more grind without substantial rewards.

[h1] TLDR: 9/10 You can visibly see the stress wafting off your body as you play this game. Slime Rancher is a almost perfectly sized game that has one of the most perfect playthrough lengths that I've ever seen. If this is your first video game ever, it's probably one of the best singelplayer games to pick. [/h1]

[b] Actual Review (Censored Spoilers): [/b] This is one of those games that you have the itch to fire up again every few years for a new playthrough, and every time you get to rediscover things you've forgotten. I played this way back on release but never finished it, and coming back over 5 years later was a delight. This is probably the most relaxing game I've ever played. You literally can just turn your brain off completely and farm. Setting up plots of land, adventuring through the wild and collecting slimes and resources to bring back, and there is even a lot of content you can choose to engage with or not, so you can tailor your playthrough as you see fit. The range exchange for example lets you open up three entire areas that aren't part of the main story and aren't needed unless you want to ramp up your ranch. Overall this game has lots of charm that never really gets old. The SINGULAR complaint that I have is the fact there is no co-op and is strictly a singleplayer experience. This game would be near perfect if it was 2 player.

There is a surprisingly good story and range of characters to interact with here. The devs made the smart decision of letting the story take the backseat and letting you discover things yourself through environmental storytelling and hidden letters. [spoiler] I will admit the ending few pieces of story and the actual ending are very abrupt, but that's really the only negative thing about it. The story itself is super interesting throughout the whole game. [/spoiler]

The gameplay is the main focus of the game. And it's a pretty simple but solid loop. Collect resources while you explore, deposit, configure/manage your ranch, repeat. There are a lot of upgradable items and tools as well as unlockable color palettes for your gear and ranch. There are also tons of treasure pods to find ranging from obvious to VERY well hidden, especially in the later areas you unlock. Thankfully they are very much worth the trouble of finding as some of them contain powerful item blueprints.

This game also has some REALLY fitting music that never gets boring to listen to. There are time of day variations of each area as well. The artstyle is also a really big plus but that's pretty evident enough.

Lastly the achievement grind wasn't bad either. There are no truly grindy achievements and the rush mode achievements aren't hard either if you have a gameplan going into it. I got all three done first try. Also I'm happy to report that most of the achievements that didn't come from playing naturally were actually fun to do, which is pretty rare!

Definitely recommend this game. One of the best to get into video games if you're new to gaming, or if you're just looking for a stress reliever. And even with no co-op, it's never not a fun time. 9/10

This game is so good that, even as someone who's not usually a huge fan of farming games, I still obsessed over it a bit too much. Incredibly fun, tons of liberty on ranch customization, very relaxing; overall an incredible game!

The only things that prevent this game from being *perfect*, in my opinion, are the following (minor) issues:

-I wish there were map markers for slime gates, treasure pods, two-way teleporters, and Gordos when you first encounter them, or at least a way to put down custom map markers yourself. I have a bad memory, and kept forgetting where things were.

-Hen coops & Onion patches are not reliable sources of foods, almost forcing you to make Largos, which feels bad.

-Felt that the 3 extra ranches were a bit complicated, but that might just be a me-problem.

Otherwise the game is as good as it gets! Highly recommend!

I am a 40 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 13 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Slime Rancher je jedinečná a neuvěřitelně příjemná hra. Vy do role mladého farmáře, který se rozhodne začít chovat slizy na vzdálené planetě. Vaším úkolem je sbírat slizy, krmit je, starat se o ně a získávat z nich různé předměty. 

Hra je vizuálně velmi příjemná a barevná. Grafika je krásná a také kreslený styl dodává hře určitý šarm. Každý sliz je odlišně vyvedený a je radost je pozorovat. Zvuková stránka hry je také perfektní a příjemná na ucho. 

Jedním z nejzábavnějších aspektů hry je explorace. Slime Rancher vás nechává objevovat rozsáhlý svět a objevovat nové druhy slizů a předmětů. Každý druh slizu má své jedinečné vlastnosti a reakce, což zpříjemňuje hru a přidává jí na dlouhodobější hratelnosti.

Hra má také dobře navržený systém upgradeů a vylepšení. Postupně budete sbírat peníze a zkušenosti, které můžete investovat do lepšího vybavení či zdokonalování farmy. To je důležité, protože vás to motivuje ke zlepšování a zdokonalování ve hře.

Jedinou možnou nevýhodou hry je, že se může zdát příliš repetitivní. Po určitém čase může chování slizů a farmování začít trochu nudit. Nicméně přidání nových druhů slizů a aktualizací hry tuto potenciální nedostatečnost vyrovnává.

Celkově je Slime Rancher skvělá hra, kterou si užijí jak milovníci farmářských her, tak i casual hráči. Krásná vizuální stránka, zábavná hratelnost a nabídka upgradeů vás potěší na dlouhé hodiny.

Let me start this by saying that this is a great game, but there's a second one now, so maybe go look into the newer one first.

So, not typically one for cutesy stuff and games, I usually play dark and grim story games or horror games or games where you're either killing people or creatures, and this game is literally none of that but I still had a fantastic time playing it. It actually became addicting to me, wanting to house every slime on my ranch and get all of the combinations possible, I enjoyed playing this even as simple as it is. Get slime, feed slime, sell plort, repeat. A simple gameplay loop, and yet, there was a ton of stuff to do and I loved it. It was nice to sit back and relax while playing instead of my other action filled games.

I will say, once you get to endgame it does feel a bit empty and repetitive. I don't exactly remember what I was trying to achieve at the end cause I'm writing this review about 3 or more years later, possibly 4, but I remember there is a place called the Glass Desert and there was something you had to do there and I just... got tired of it because it was insanely repetitive or difficult to do. It may have been for an achievement or something, as I said, don't remember, so maybe it wasn't something you even had to do. Anyway, this is a cute and fun game and I liked listening to music while playing. I even went ahead and 100%-ed it recently too (which was a little difficult but I managed).

So if you're looking for a relaxing game to play while also getting away from all the other action-filled, killing games, then play Slime Rancher, but I do suggest you go look at the newer one because this one isn't being updated anymore and is a bit outdated now. 7.5/10.

I've wanted this game for almost 7 years, having watched every play through I could get my hands on as a kid. It was genuinely so up my alley as a 12 year old, I knew I needed to get it once I was reminded of it's existence late last year. I played it for about 20~ hours initially, moved, and finally finished it at around 45~ hours. It has a great game play loop, lots of replay value through things like rush mode and the multitude of mini games it provides, and is a great game to either multitask to or just let your mind go to ease. I've had awesome nights staying up late with friends and talking while playing, and I've also had really good afternoons putting in an hour or two. The slime designs are adorable, and trying to maximize plort value in market by manipulating slime combinations was genuinely entertaining. I was just gifted the second game, and cannot wait to play and see where the dev team goes with it! 10/10 game!!

This game is absolutely stellar! It's a slow burn though, it takes a few hours to start really getting into it but once you've started really honing your farming and plort-collecting capabilities you're golden (slime)! 

Spoiler-ish:

I've found it takes a while to get some quality of life upgrades and it's much closer to something like stardew valley in terms of progression. The story line is so fucking stellar that when I hit end-game and read the FINAL note (which I had not read literally any of because I'd be skipping them) I immediately went back and read them all and cried. I'm now onto slime rancher 2 which is also stellar but way more grind-y. I've got quite a few hours on both games and I really enjoy them, but I do take extended breaks between grind sessions because I get so annoyed the next section hasn't unlocked yet. I'm also a mild completionist so that adds another level of frustration because I don't use walkthroughs. My only suggestion is get to the tallest spot on any section of the map and you will find hidden shit. 

Overall, I adore this game. I just got back into slime rancher 2 a few days ago and I fell back in love. I suggest this to anyone who enjoys chill farming and squishy buddies!

LASTLY: USE. THE. BEES. And don't forget to splash them with water to wake them up. You can't run a farm on your own ya know!

Slime Rancher is a first person exploration-platformer game suitable for kids or tired adults, with some light farming mechanics. At its heart is a goofy ecosystem-regulation mechanic where slimes can grow and merge their attributes together by eating each other's poop, but if a fully grown slime eats another kind of poop, it mutates into a Tarr monster that eats other slimes. In this way, environments regulate themselves from getting overpopulated by too many different slimes, and you're encouraged to keep high value slimes on your farm in their own pens for safety.

A large portion of the game is simply solid first person platforming. The world is built with satisfying loops and winding pathways,and as you level up your jetpack you can discover shortcuts over mountain ridges and secrets nestled in the world geometry. As you upgrade your farm, you also unlock new shortcuts and areas that establish your farm as a seamless part of the world with plenty of its own potential to unlock.

At its heart, Slime Rancher is about exploration. Despite this sim aspects, it's pretty unlikely that you'll lose any serious progress in this game, though the post-game Rush mode is a legitimate challenge to your comprehension of the world and its mechanics. There's a light story that gently guides you through the game's various environments, but because of how grind-heavy the game's story mode can be, it's not particularly well-suited for replaying. That said, a complete save file is a fine little sandbox, and if you like setting your own goals or achievement hunting there's enough to keep you coming back here and there.

Over the years this has become one of my most returned-to games on Steam just for the low-stress, holistic, and mischievous little world Monomi Park has created. Despite its humble looks, Slime Rancher is the full package, and has set quite a high bar for its sequel.

I feel Slime Rancher is one of the greatest indie games of all time, but that may just be personal. 

The story, although very fun, with character arcs you can really get invested in, feels like it was an afterthought sometimes. There are a small cast of characters, who all have an arc that the player gets to go through and help influence. Mochi, Hugo, Victor, among others. Casey, or anyone else, all characters in the story. However, the characters can sometimes feel like they get overshadowed by the ranching experience, which I feel is just fine, actually. Although I would wish for more time to talk to your love interest on earth, or your new friends across the universe, the time you get in incredible and precious.The gameplay is great. The ranching experience, taking care of adorable slimes that love to see you, the exploration of the massive and beautiful world, with new creatures and lore to find, and things to do in every moment, no matter when you think you're done. Hell, even if you don't enjoy either aspect of that, there is so much you can do outside of that. Reading letters, or going through a small visual novel through the characters, and finding more with fun mini-games, or, even if you don't find joy in those things or concepts, you can plan, space out slimes and machines, and plan it out to be so incredibly efficient, that you can relax and just play with silly slimes. You can even play with the games market, saving your plorts, or selling them to make the most money.

Overall, if you enjoy story that involves you, gameplay that includes exploration and planning, and just adorable creatures and beautiful worlds, I'd try the game.

(100% completion update)

This game is simple, sweet, and oddly charming; albeit, tedious at times. I would say there isn't much endgame content other than achievements, but what you do get is great. The lack of endgame is forgivable for how long one can invest hours upon hours into this game.

As for 100%, there is no "real 100%" other than the story and achievements. One could theoretically play this game forever. So, Obviously, I have all the achievements and the story is complete. I went a few steps further to get all the locations, all the unlocks, all the recipes, all the treasure pods, upgrades, 7Zee rewards club tiers, a farm that is able to produce every farm-able type of slime automatically, and having crafted everything at least once. Needless to say, I covered every base of this game, even if I didn't get an achievement for it. As for the "Adventure mode" achievements, they're all doable. Might have to look a few things up from time to time, but yes, very possible.

As for the "Rush Mode" achievements; I recommend you 100% the "Adventure Mode." Having a knowledge of the layout will help ALOT in "Rush Mode." I was able to get all three achievements for "Rush Mode" in one go, but, keep in mind, I probably played this game WAY longer than most would. I had some help from guides, and I was able to get everything done right away, and thus, 100%'ed the game. I recommend this mode last, as it is the most stressful thing in this entire game, where every second of time is more precious than any resource available. 

For a casual players, probably a solid 8/10. (Reason: There is no end-game content besides achievements and/or maxing out your farm like I did.)

For the 100-er's: 10/10: (You will always find something to upgrade, make better, or whatever.) (Not too impossible, and not too stress inducing if you have the knowledge and skill.)

As or me, a solid 10/10. Worth every dollar. (Not penny, b/c change crisis)

Absolutely incredible game.  As someone who doesn't purchase games too often, I'm so glad I bought this one.  It's not everyone's forte, of course, but it's 100% mine, with lots of exploring, story, some thinking, and lots of calming factors (with some threatening undertones).  I must admit that I rushed the game a bit, and looked some stuff up online to finish it, which I probably wouldn't have had to do if I had been patient.  Either way, i absolutely adored this game, and I'm excited to get the rest of the achievements, all of the secrets, and get started on the second game (although maybe slower this time, so I can take my time and enjoy it to it's fullest).

Firstly, I am NOT good at these first person games and get lost all the time.  And savaged by wandering abominations.  I also tend to walk off things and plummet to my virtual death.  
But I am enjoying Slime Rancher on creative mode, with no enemies and a "rest" period penalty for almost killing yourself rather than a "game over'.  Yeah, you lose your stuff but better than reloading a save.
The little slimes, with their happy faces and "wheeeeee's" as you hurl them around just make me smile.  I've never seen anybody look so happy to be shot into cages and walls and off cliffs in my life.
I do wish the upgrades you buy in the house for fences and walkways were more obvious and you could pick and choose.  Seems so far that you have to buy upgrades in the order they come up to get to the good stuff.
And I wish the chickens weren't so cute.  I feel bad when I feed them to the slimes.
But all in all.....Wheeeeee!

After being the second game I have ever bought, I had played Slime Rancher too quickly in my earlier days and ended up quitting before ever reaching the end. Years later, I returned to 100% the game... And in doing so, I had the joy of experiencing all that Slime Rancher has to offer. I had jumped into the game believing it would be a quick shot to the end, but as time had passed the game went from silly fun to taking care of my slimes with all that I could. I was locked into the game with such an immersion that I felt a great connection to the slimes I had in my ranch that I kept through the entire game. Almost all of the experience is unpredictable- leading to all sorts of surprises that kept me from losing that immersion. Brimming with love and care in every aspect, it is the simplicity of it that makes it so charming. There is so little if anything to dislike about this game. And after completing it, I can safely say that Slime Rancher was 100% worth playing.

One day, I was a little bored, and was browsing my steam library. Until I found a little game called slime rancher. I remembered trying the sequel on console a few years back, and remembered playing the game a lot when I was younger, around 2017-2018. Having fond memories of the game when it was in its earlier stages, and seeing my lackluster achievements, I decided to give it another shot. Now, a couple days later, 50 more hours in the game, and with every single achievement unlocked. I can tell you, with confidence, that this game, is amazing! And to be honest, i feel as though I've done the game a disservice by having such a great experience collecting dust in my library for so long. Please, PLEASE give this game another shot if you've over looked it in the past. The game is extremely cute, relaxing, and even has a very heartfelt and, almost tragic story aswell between the Beatrix LeBeau and her lover that she left on earth. Once again, please play this game and i promise you will not regret it.

This has been my favourite game for a good while now, and I loved every second of it. To start it off, this game is about collecting cute little blobs called 'slimes' and putting them in a corral to feed, and make money from, as most reading this would know, although it is more than just that. When you get a good amount of money, you get the chance to upgrade your ranch, vacpack, etc. I personally love this game from the lovely graphics, adorable characters, and free will to do anything and go anywhere on the map! along with the different types of gameplay you can choose (casual, adventure and rush), along with the theme and looks for me creates an outstanding game. I would recommend this to any person who likes taking it easy, and people who enjoy long-lasting gameplay.

I really love the variety of fun things to do in slime rancher, the adventure aspect, and the logic aspect in the stock market! Then there's also the great music, the slimepedia, the decorations, and I love the 7Zsee rewards club! There's always something to do! The characters are so nice and feel so real, too! They feel like real people with their own personality and lives. They're so fleshed out! The only things that I wish they had was a co-op mode with someone like B0b as the other player or something, or more story for Ogden. I also wonder if Victor was always as scientific as he is

There are so many things to do here, you can build your ranch the way you want with tons of customisations and even slime hybrids. There is also many places to explore and player upgrades. i review games on steam after i 100% complete them! check out my reviews to see all the games i have completed!

slime rancher, developed & published by monomi park, is a charming and unique life simulation game that invites players to explore the whimsical world of the "far, far range" where you capture, cultivate, and nurture a plethora of different creatures of different variants known as slimes.

the gameplay is the heart and soul of its core appeal. the mechanics are responsive and intuitive, and the main gameplay loop involves exploring the far, far range, capturing different slime, and then managing your ranch. there's even more hardcore mechanics that are done especially well here such as a day/night cycle, a weather system, creating a dynamic ecosystem that keeps the gameplay fresh and engaging throughout the entire journey to 100% completion.

visually, there's a vibrant and appealing art style. slimes have distinctive designs and environments are also colorful and immersive. the game strikes a perfect balance between simplicity and complexity, ensuring that players can easily distinguish between different elements while enjoying a visually pleasing experience. you might get some frame drops but they are extremely minor and extremely uncommon, so they don't detract from the overall enjoyment at all.

there's satisfying sound effects all over the game, whether it's the slimes bouncing around or the sound when you suck up resources, overall the audio design is great. the one drawback/negative i can point out is that the music, while charming and pleasing to listen to, can become repetitive over longer sessions.

there is a staggering amount of content for completionists specifically. from collecting every type of slime and resource to unlocking secret areas and discovering hidden treasures, the game consistently rewards exploration and dedication. the addition of numerous achievements and challenges provides a clear and concise roadmap for players striving for 100% completion, ensuring a sense of accomplishment with each milestone achieved.

the post-launch support from monomi park has been exemplary, with frequent updates introducing new content, slimes, and features. this ongoing support adds longevity to the game, encouraging players to return and experience fresh challenges.

there's a exceptionally high replay value here as well. no two playthroughs are exactly alike and even after achieving 100% completion you could continue playing the game, as you could try different strategies, create new challenges for yourself, or just simply enjoy the world crafted by the devs. 

slime rancher is a delightful and captivating little experience that excels in gameplay, graphics, and content. its accessible mechanics make it enjoyable for players of all ages, while the depth and complexity of its systems provide a rewarding experience for those seeking 100% completion. the undeniable charm on display here makes slime rancher a must-play title and achieving100% completion is a satisfying journey through a whimsical world.

I have many reasons why I loved this game. Firstly, its variety, you can play it in a very casual way (with no problems to encounter, which is the mode I most like) or with the challenge of Tarrs and other things. Secondly, I like a lot the soundtrack, if you wear headphones you can feel as if you were at the place that you currently are, and it is very relaxing it good to hear. I have more motives for why I like this game, but I personally think that those, said before, are two good reasons to be said in a "fast" review for steam community. I really suggest that you buy this game, it's worth it, I bought it in sale for R$6. Thank you developers for this game, you have done a great job!

Bright, colorful, and lighthearted. Slime Rancher really brings FPS to the farming sim genre in an adorable way. Taking place on a very distant planet, Beatrix LeBeau, our protagonist, must make her mark on this alien world. Taking over the ranch from an old Slime farmer to return it to its former glory.

- Fun, unique environments Each area is very distinct from the last. Having its own aesthetics, slime, and food to observe and collect.
- Your weapon is a vacuum! Use it to collect more than 16 different slime types to take back to your ranch and corral!
- Feed and combine slimes to produce a variety of 'plorts' that can be exchanged on the market for 'Newbucks' the in-game currency.
- Build up the ranch your way with several unique buildings including corrals, gardens, silos, teleportation portals, and plenty of decorations and color schemes to make it your own! 
- Upgrade your character with a better Vacpak Gun, jetpack, dash boots, and more!
- Three different modes to choose from, including a time trial style for an added challenge. 

- While the story does conclude, there is no end to the game itself. You are free to continue for as long as you would like to customize, grow, and challenging yourself. While this might appeal to some players, this isn't really for me. 
- The actual "farming/ranching" part of the game did lose its appeal and became very mundane after some time. While this is the game at its core, with such an interesting world to explore and little secrets to find, I found myself actually neglecting the ranch itself until I ran out of funds and needed to replenish.

Over all, the game was quite a bit of fun. It is a nice distraction from some of the more serious titles that many people might be playing. Even if it's only a pick up for a little here and there, it's fun to just explore a positive world every once in a while!

- Stay Wiggly!

This game is good for when you just want to wind up and relax. With its cute graphics and even cutest slimes, you can work on your farm and slowly discover more and more of the slime world. Almost all gates that you open with the slime keys has areas to discover with new slimes that you can colect and bring back to your farm. The possibility to make the slimes large makes it makes for strategy. What slimes do you combine? What food will you feed them with? With each slime having abilities that makes them easier or harder to contain it is fun to figure out how to care of your slimes in you farm. Together with the unique looks for each slime you can see that there was care put into this game.

There is lot to do, from helping the other farmers with their quests like collecting fruit, racing and collecting silver plorts or trying to find the impostor glitch slimes which is great break from the repetivness of taking care of your slime.

The crafting system also makes it easier to take care of the slimes in the end. One thing that I didn't like but it mostly my thing is the fact that at the end the drones are necessity rather than easy acessibility as taking care of all your slimes will take all the time that you won't be able to really wander off to other ranches. However the recipe for drones is quite expensive that it takes a while before you can craft your first drone.

This can make mid game and end game difficult.

Still. I would recommend to try this game.

Overall pretty good story to just relax to.

[h1]Ston's Slime Rancher Review[/h1]
Even though my best friend -> that kind of introduced me to slime rancher <- loved this game ever since i 
met him i never really came around to play it until very recently. It always looked like a cool game and just whimsical experience from afar and after completing it's story i can only confirm that. But it's also so much more.

[h3]☆Graphics and Design☆[/h3]
I think slime ranchers art style has to be one of the most loved aspects of the game. It's so adorable, yet not overly complicated which just works out so so well. It also has something very unique about it that the sequel took and MASTERED a few years later. My only criticism about it all would be the map design. It's not bad, not by any means, but i would be lying if i'd tell you i wasn't fed up traversing this map after 20 hours of playtime (that's probably also because that's a lot of time to be fair). And, of course, the slimes are so adorable it physically hurts to look at them.

[h3]☆Gameplay☆[/h3]
I don't really have much to say about this section next to that i really enjoyed the gameplay all the way through. The game gives you a lot of freedom with whatever you want to do and lets you customize your ranch in plenty ways also which is always welcome. It's simplicity and calming atmosphere is great and achieving something (like adding a valuable upgrade to your ranch) feels so amazing. Oh, and the slimes are still so CUTE I CAN'T TAKE IT ANYMORE.

[h3]☆Story☆[/h3]
Okay, first off,,, the concept of being almost entirely isolated on a far away planet is so special to me. It really spoke to me, felt somehow relatable and just made me want to leave and become a slime rancher too. Bea is a super enjoyable main character and the NPCs are a very memorable bunch. Casey's and bea's realationship was something that stuck out to me though. It was THE part of the story i loved most and always looked forward to continue.

So yeah, all in one this game has been incredible and the only reason i declared it "finished" is because i cannot wait to play slime rancher 2. If it's anything like its predecessor i know i will eat it up too.

Slime Rancher is a very good game, I recommend it to everyone!a very pleasant atmosphere, the plot and translations into almost all languages!this game I really like the plot, the sweet atmosphere and the GLASS DESERT, it is very fascinating at the same time scary, but nevertheless my favorite location.Why?.This location is really strange in this place, time has frozen, when you get to this location you will see a crown of strangely shaped huge sculptures made of glass, but it's not glass, it's just echoes of the time when the desert was a volcano, but at one moment everything froze all the tongues of fire turned into glass.This place has a very peculiar atmosphere, as in every location in this game, do you like the mysterious ruins or the indigo quarry, or maybe a fascinating forest?All of this can be found there and even more.I HIGHLY RECOMMEND IT (I think it's just my unhealthy love for this game, because I have the best childhood memories associated with it :)

A relaxing game of running around, exploring, and wrangling slimes. Couple of things to note however. 

1. Despite claims, this game will not work with Xbox One or Series X|S controllers (via Bluetooth) unless you enable Steam's input. This will cause occasional issues with things like the vacgun blast being triggered when you try to close a menu and sometimes you will get erratic movement when controller batteries get low. 

2. Don't expect any kind of story, it's literally just running around collecting slimes, feeding them to make them generate plorts, and then selling those or using them to make things. 

3. The tutorials could really be better, but it's not too difficult to figure out how to do things with some trial and error.

4. The four tanks limit will get real old real quick, especially when you try to explore some of the further reaches. It's also really difficult to tell which tank you have selected at any given time. Hopefully this will be addressed in Slime Rancher 2 at some point. You can get a mod to change this, thankfully. Otherwise it's just too much back and forth and trying to manage your inventory which makes the game more like work than fun.

If this game is on sale, like the $5 I got it for, it's definitely worth it. At full price it would be a more difficult value proposition.

Rating: ★★★★☆ (4/5 gooey stars)

Slime Rancher is the cutest intergalactic adventure you never knew you needed – a squishy, bouncy, slime-tastic romp through the extraterrestrial farmlands. Get ready to embark on a journey where the only danger is getting too attached to your adorable, gelatinous livestock. Here's our whimsical take on Slime Rancher:

Graphics: ★★★★☆
Prepare your eyes for an explosion of color and cuteness! The vibrant, cartoonish graphics make you feel like you've stepped into a whimsical world of gooey wonders. From the jiggly slimes to the plump vegetables, the visual charm of Slime Rancher is enough to make even the grumpiest gamer crack a smile.

Gameplay: ★★★★★
Forget saving the world or defeating epic bosses; in Slime Rancher, your main goal is to gather as many squishy slimes as possible and manage your very own slime ranch. It's like farming, but with more bouncing blobs and less hay. The sheer joy of bouncing around collecting adorable creatures and watching them go about their slimy business is oddly satisfying.

Slime Variety: ★★★★★
From the standard pink slimes to the quirky phosphor slimes that glow in the dark, Slime Rancher boasts a rainbow of gooey diversity. Each slime has its own unique personality and quirks, making slime-wrangling a delightfully unpredictable experience. Just try not to get too attached to those googly-eyed faces.

Vacpack Gadgets: ★★★☆☆
The Vacpack, your trusty vacuum-like tool, is your best friend and multitool on the ranch. While it's fun to vacuum up slimes and resources, some of the gadgets are a bit wonky. The jetpack may send you soaring into the stratosphere when all you wanted was a gentle hop. But hey, it adds to the wacky charm!

Economy: ★★★★☆
Who knew that plort, the adorable name for slime poop, would become the currency of the land? The economy in Slime Rancher is as quirky as the game itself. Selling plorts and upgrading your ranch provides a satisfying sense of progression, even if you're scratching your head at the thought of a slime-based financial system.

Charm Factor: ★★★★★
Slime Rancher oozes charm – pun intended. The whimsical soundtrack, the goofy expressions of the slimes, and the overall feel-good atmosphere make this game a delightful escape from the more serious titles in your library. It's impossible not to crack a grin when a tabby slime gives you that adorable wide-eyed stare.

In conclusion, Slime Rancher is a bouncy, gooey, and downright charming adventure that will leave you with a heart full of warmth and a backpack full of plorts. It's a game that embraces the silly side of gaming, reminding us that sometimes, all you need is a handful of slimes to turn your day around. Grab your Vacpack and get ready to squish, bounce, and ranch your way to slimy success!

Slimer Rancher is a great chill farming sim with a twist - the slimes.

I enjoyed my time with it.

It lacks some quality of life improvements (for example the FOV only goes up to 90), but it's still a great game.

The only big problem I had with it was the ending. (Spoiler-free)
It was anticlimactic and confusing. 
The best way to prove this is the fact that, according to Steam stats, more than 6% of players fulfilled all the requirements for the ending, but just literally didn't notice, because they didn't get the ending achievement.
That's all I'm gonna say so as to not spoil it, but if you get frustrated and don't know what you're supposed to do next, just Google it.

While I love this game, and at first found it very relaxing, it started making me feel sick. Like motion sickness, I took a few breaks and had someone help me change the resolution a couple times, which normally helps some on certain games, it didn't help this one. That motion type sickness can be pre-seizure warnings so I eventually stopped playing (I was having fun, as it it quite addictive and fun so my desire to play outweighed common sense to stop). I contacted Steam and they refused a refund because I played it too long, regardless of health issues I explained.  I get motion sickness, have vestibular, aura, and regular migraines, and am at risk for seizures. Due to how long I played last night I still feel sick today.  My point is It is a fun game and relaxing but if you are prone to motion sickness, seizures, or migraines I would not chance these games and steam will steal your money for them if you find you cannot play them.

Fun and cute, to sum it up in three words! It's hard to get bored while playing because there is simply so much to do. 

Collecting Slimes while waiting for your crops to grow, gathering resources to build drones or decorations, sorting out areas to where you grow crops, keep chickens and have slime enclosures. Then trying to make the weirdest Slime combinations, because why not.

At some point, I left The Grotto without any slime enclosures and let them roam free with a few crops so they don't starve, my little bee drones make sure all is organised and even so, there's still so much to do. It's also fun mixing the Slimes with all kinds of other types!

I also recommended this game to a friend with anxiety and they've said it helps them calm down, that's a win in my book!

I got this game pretty early with no expectation for much in the lore itself, and yet I was pleasantly surprised. After taking a break from the game I came back to a much more expansive and fleshed out version to make it all the more addicting, not only that, but the Devs continuously work on the game!

You can tell the Developers are passionate and do care about their game as well as the community. I certainly recommend this game if you simply want to relax and enjoy the colourful scenery, OR have an epic adventure with the story, and that's the best part, you can chose how you want to play and it will massively impact your experience.

"Slime Rancher" is for the casual, cozy gamer who is looking for a cute and relaxing farming simulator. The mechanics of the game are simple enough for new gamers to catch on quickly, taking on a classic FPS perspective with none of the gore. This game is a masterpiece. The game is extremely well done. The aesthetic is very cute, the progression, farming, exploration, and achievements are all excellently put together.

[b][u]Exploration:[/u][/b]
Very few games still allow me to feel the excitement of exploration and reward, wanting to find out what's around the next corner, and having a world that's open, diverse, and unique enough to allow for this type of journey. Dark Souls and Skyrim are the only two modern game I can think of that have been able to do that, so this was a pleasant surprise from Slime Rancher.
You get a jetpack, which allows you to move horizontally a good distance, and a little bit vertically. This unique situation creates a fun almost puzzle like experience to try and get onto the highest structures, and look for little treasures, or new paths to zones. I probably spent half my playtime just climbing the mountains exploring. As you explore you find new slimes, which change the way you set up your ranch.

[b][u]Farming:[/u][/b]
The farming aspect is very unique. The dev team seems like a really creative bunch. You can farm regular crops and chickens, which is fun. However, the interesting part is the slime mechanics. You have to be able to keep them under control, where each has different variables to account for. Each has a unique diet, so you need to plan accordingly, which enters an almost strategic element to farming, which I don't think I've ever seen before. The slimes can also combine, and you can set up drones for automation.
There's also a science development mechanic where you creates gadgets to help you farm or explore. This requires gathering new resources and crafting new items. The crazy thing here, there's TONS of resources to collect, and they all serve a purpose, which is a lot of fun.

[b][u]Upgrades:[/u][/b]
There's a bunch of upgrades that you simply purchase. While simple, it's still a nice addition. You can upgrade your vacuum (the tool you use everything for), your health, jetpack, and the plots of land for gardening and slimes and what not. It's sort of a gate at times, where you need to get better in some regard, in order to make it to the next area, either by buying an expansion, growing new slimes, getting a new upgrade, etc. It's a neat way of setting it up so you can't just go everywhere immediately. This way, you get to intimately know each area, grow to love the different maps, and get even more excited to go explore the new place you just unlocked.

[b][u]Slimeopedia:[/u][/b]
There is an in-game wiki, which is made really well. I've read every entry, because they're well written, funny, informative, and not too long. This helps you progress in the game without having to go look things up on the internet, which is great. I hate when games don't tell you anything, and it's nearly impossible to figure out, so you have to look online. With Slime Rancher, the info is all built into the game, and they did it in a fun way. Some of the writing in it is actually really clever.

[b][u]Achievements:[/u][/b]
One of the things I hate most with game devs is when they butcher the achievements, making me hate the game before I'm done. This game thankfully does NOT do that! The achievements in this game are extremely well thought out. There's your typical progression ones, then ones that make you do something unique you never would have tried otherwise, ones that are difficult, and then the ones you really need to work for, that will require you to look at the game differently. The achievements actually add gameplay, which is how it should be. They also aren't unreasonable, making it completely possible to 100% the game, without getting frustrated and hating the game before you're done. I definitely recommend this to completionists. The way the game is built is actually for the completionist sort of mentality. You actually want to explore everything, own everything, find everything. Also, they didn't make achievements that they very easily could have, but that would have ruined the game, like finding every piece of treasure. If that were an achievement, it would have dragged the experience out, making it worse. They did not do that, which I imagine was a deliberate act on their part, because they're smart enough to know what will make good achievements. They put some real thought into them, and it shows.

[b][u]Good for kids:[/u][/b]
Editing my review to add this. My kids are 6 and 4, and they love it. It's quite easy (which is also a downside, see next point), so even little kids can get right into it. There's no real permanent mistakes you can make, so you can always recover. They can just let loose with their creativity, and making a mess of things. Just be aware you might have to help them if they mess stuff up too badly, haha. Also, you might have to protect them from the bad guys when they start screaming, lol.

[b][u]The Downside:[/u][/b]
I took my time with the game, just enjoying it, and I'm at 40 hours, with very little left to do. I'll probably still play for a while to get the last few achievements, but just note that it's not something like Minecraft, where you can play endlessly. You get to a point where your ranch is nearly perfect, you have total automation set up, you have all the upgrades, every type of slime, etc. and you're just sitting back watching the money pile up. At that point, there's nothing left to do. You've explored everything, own everything, and have mastered the world.
Now that said, 50-60 hours is good for a game, I'm just saying don't expect more than what it provides. It's a simple yet extremely unique and creative experience, definitely worth your time, and then you're done, and you can move on to other things.

Another downside is that it is a little on the easy side. The monster slimes (tarrs) don't really pose much of a threat. For example, my three year old daughter is playing this game with me on her own ranch. She's been surrounded by the tarrs, and she was panicking all scared, and I was able to coach her through it, without touching the controller, and she got away, and didn't even reach half health. She doesn't even know how to hold the controller properly, and has played very little video games. Just realize that the game isn't meant to be "hard" in that sense.

[b][u]Overall:[/u][/b]
I highly recommend this game. It's been one of the more enjoyable games I've played in a long time, and I will always look back on it fondly. Even if you just look at the stats, 22% of the people who have started the game up have completed it, which is quite high for a game. It shows that people who actually start playing it typically enjoy it enough to finish it.

When you unlock the player teleporter, you need it direly. There's no direct portal to the Glass Desert and you're expected to craft your own or go on monotonous treks through the same biomes again and again and again.

Unfortunately, unlocking the teleporter is not enough. You need to craft it. That takes a diamond. Diamonds are a material that you need, and you can only get it by mining for materials you don't need until you eventually rank up to the next drill and the next.

Is drilling fun? No. Enjoy doing it for hours just to finally get access to a QoL upgrade that the rest of the game will assume you already have. This isn't helped by the fact that the core gameplay loop is finding a gordo, emptying your pockets into their mouth, and kicking rocks on your way home because almost EVERY single obstacle in this game takes at least two trips. This game is full of baffling choices like that, like the fact that side paths and main paths use the same keys and biomes don't unlock all at once. You could find yourself taking bizarre detours getting to a spot that should be right in front of you, and you might even find those bizarre detours becoming your main route because you still don't have teleporters.

Very addicting to play.
As someone who likes making things efficient, this is a game that both fuels and annoys that itch, since a lot of the game is maintaining your ranch but also needing to explore the world. I found myself a lot of times spending many in game days tending to the ranch and forgetting about the exploration aspect just because they make the ranch gameplay loop very addicting.
Though I do like how they integrated the lore and story into the game even though it is mostly through letters. A sense of discovery and adventure is prevalent and captures it well.
It does take a while to understand how everything works, especially since the game doesn't hold your hand and lets you free before you even understand what you're doing so get ready for that before you start playing.
Overall a really fun simulation, farming, management, and exploration game.

Life is pain, every waking moment pure agony. I crawl through the infernal hellhole called life, my futile existence smothered by unquenchable misery. Little by little, day by day I sink deeper and deeper into the bottomless pit of anguish that is my suffering. My existence is that of a jester, a fool. My presence is a mere footnote in the all encompassing story of life. To think otherwise would be the height of folly, a sin against the matter of truth. Life is torment, existence is pain, continuation is anguish. These are the truths of my world. Yet I keep on living. Moving, though I see no end. Fighting, though I sense no victory. Dreaming, though I know no paradise. A lifetime of struggle, this ceaseless journey that I travel. I claim it. For what is life if not struggle. Without it I would be nothing, a senseless husk of myself. And thus it is precious to me, though I buy it with great pain. I must keep on ranching slimes. The plorts must flow.

Slime Rancher Review

Audio: 9/10 - cute noises, music is decent

Balance: 8/10 - pretty easy, but it’s a casual game so that’s the point

Design: 8/10 - design is fine, but can get cluttered

Fun: 9/10 - flying around with a jetpack and shooting slimes into the ocean but some of the puzzles are a bit grindy or confusing

Gameplay: 9/10 - exploration is interesting and the farming system is well built

Graphics: 9/10 - graphics are cute but nothing groundbreaking

Extras: 7/10 - none that I’ve ever tested, but there are a few such as the Secret Style Pack

Playtime: 9/10 - very long, kind of game you can put down for a few months and pick up right where you left off

Stability: 10/10 - never encountered any problems

Story: 8/10 - story is pretty good but nothing especially memorable

Total: 86 honey slime plorts out of 100

you can ranch slimes

My favorite type of game is "collect creature and have an index of creature collected" and if that's also your favorite, this is a great game! The story-line is cute, the art is charming, and the jokes are great! 
My only issue is that it made my laptop overheat SO badly. I didn't play the game for more than 10 minutes at time without my keyboard trying to roast my fingertips. After several years of the game collecting dust in my library [strike]- and me pouting about how it's such a fun game and I'm so bummed that my gaming laptop can't run it -[/strike] I FINALLY found that you can change the FPS rate of programs in NVIDIA control panel! She runs at a smooooooth 30fps now which, honestly, doesn't have that much of a difference in quality in my opinion!
So, get this game! It's amazing! Just please for the love of all the stars above, find a way to change the fps rate of the game yourself until the devs decide that they want to include it in the settings.

[h1]Truly Beautiful[/h1]

[i]There will be a TL;DR at the end[/i]

~

When I first got this game on a Steam Sale, I was curious enough to install it and give it a try.
I thought that it would be a few moments of my adult mind being bored by the twee charms of an experience clearly crafted for small children.
It was a pleasant surprise when the game pulled me into its world and beckoned me further and further away from the ranch in a seemingly endlessly expanding adventure of new areas, new slimes, and unique ways to approach them.
After over 30 hours to date, there are still areas I have not yet explored and still some data entries that I haven't caught yet.

Not only is there always more to do, but the simplicity of the game's foundation mixed with its ebb and flow of managing the ranch and venturing out into the Far Far Range.

There's not much to the story itself - with it being more of a search for diary entries than anything fully engrossing (Or Distracting)

The aspect of nurturing your ranch from a dry plot of land into a sprawling complex with every kind of slime imaginable is exquisite. It's beyond addictive, it is fulfilling and interfaces seamlessly.

The graphics and overall game feel is sweet, but also impressive. Unlike many modern 'Cozy' or 'Cute' games that have the staying power of cotton candy, fading away the instant it is consumed, [i]Slime Rancher[/i]'s charm and unique appeal make it a memory that sticks with you. It's been years since I first play it, and the fond memories of exploring the levels and hunting down resources still comes to mind at times.

The journey is organic, interesting, and sucked me in for hours upon hours before I could even bring myself to be responsible enough to put it down - but it was a warm and familiar thing for me to return to.

When darkness swells inside the soul and the tempest rages around you, the Far Far Range is still waiting for you to return and fall in love with its charm all over again. It is a trusted friend that will comfort you and make you smile even in the worst of times.

The developers have made something truly special.
From its charming presentation in music, sight, and sense - to the addicting gameplay of gathering slimes and the resources that they need to thrive in order to expand your ever-growing ranch - [i]Slime Rancher[/i] is something that I will never forget, and will fondly return to whenever I need something to warm my soul in a wholesome way.

This is not simply a game for young children. It is a creative spark brought to life in a display of talent, love, and competence.

~

[h3]TL;DR[/h3]
[b]8.5/10[/b].
[i]Slime Rancher[/i] is an [b]Excellent[/b] experience.
Teeming with life and the unstoppable power of joy, growth, and curiosity - the game will melt your heart until it's a happy goo content to hop around a truly wonderful place.

[h1] Slime Rancher: A Bouncy, Colorful Delight [/h1]

Allow me to introduce you to "Slime Rancher," a game that might make you question your claims of having a respectable adult job. I've spent the last 30 hours of my life corralling bouncy, adorable blobs and trading their... let's say, "resources" on the stock market or for scientific purposes. Now, how do I explain this to my exercise class buddies without losing all credibility? It's a tricky task.

"Slime Rancher" places you in the boots of Beatrix LeBeau, a rancher marooned a thousand light years from Earth. Your mission? Build a ranch, expand your horizons in the alien world, and, oh yes, deal with the wacky creatures that call this place home.

The game kicks off with a modest house on a barren piece of land. Little squares indicate where you can construct structures to house your slimes or cultivate resources. It's pretty lifeless, except for the bouncy pink blobs bounding around in their perpetual state of joy, occasionally cooing over a carrot.

Your initiation into the ranching business is quite straightforward. The game teaches you the basics: how to vacuum slimes into your backpack, deposit them in pens, and feed them carrots to induce the, let's say, digestive process. Their colorful excrements, called plorts, take center stage in the game's systems.

Plorts are the lifeblood of your endeavors. Early on, it's all about vacuuming up plorts and tossing them into the plort market to turn a profit. As you amass currency, you can unlock a lab area, where plorts combine with other resources to create decorations and labor-saving gadgets for your ranch. They also hold the key to unlocking secrets in the regions you'll explore.

Slimes come in various flavors, with the basic pink slimes being the easiest to manage. They'll eat anything and are consequently less valuable on the plort market. Market prices fluctuate based on supply and demand, and I learned that flooding the market daily results in lower profits. For a min-maxer, waiting for opportune moments might be the way to go. However, I took a more relaxed approach.

Here's where things get interesting. Slimes can, shall we say, crossbreed if they consume plorts from different species. This leads to fascinating results, like giant pink tabby cat blobs or glow-in-the-dark rocky hybrids. These hybrid slimes have advantages, as they can consume the food of both parent species. However, they take up more space and are harder to contain, leading to costlier pen requirements.

Things get truly chaotic if you mix too many different slimes together. They can turn into nightmarish Tarrs, which will obliterate everything on your ranch. It's a lesson I learned the hard way.

But the game's real charm lies in the balance between exploring the alien world and expanding your homestead. As you venture out to new places, gathering crops and resources, you'll gradually familiarize yourself with these unique spaces. Your farming skills and technology will grow, prompting you to revisit earlier areas for fresh opportunities.

After around 30 hours, I felt content with my ranching adventure. The game's limitations started to wear on me, and grinding for more money felt less appealing. A desire for more automation in farming also surfaced. I wanted crops to be automatically deposited and plorts to be divided between the market and lab. While automation might have reduced the mundane tasks, it would have left me with too little to do.

Furthermore, the ranch's layout felt quite restrictive, especially when decorating. I wished for more freedom in placing structures and elements.

Despite these quirks, "Slime Rancher" offers a delightful 30-hour experience filled with exploration, mystery, and adorable chaos. The game's secrets unravel at a pleasing pace, and its whimsical world is a joy to discover. It's a bouncy rainbow in a gaming landscape dominated by drab shooters. I couldn't be happier that a game like Slime Rancher exists.
