10/10

Pure torture and absolute nightmare for those who wanna get to the end AND for obsessive players. Map design is confusing and indistinguishable near and after the end even with reference to tutorial videos. Still haven’t unlocked all the ancient water fountains. Big slimes are also misleading-they could be access to critical areas or simply some nonsense materials that could’ve been obtained effortlessly otherwise, and it’s more than frustrating when the latter happens (majority of the time). Frustration turns to torture with the movement system. Didn’t ask you to be Valkyrie in Apex Legends, but at least the avatar shouldn’t be shooting the a££ out of her feeble farting jetpack while only be able to reach 4 feet high. BTW, this dumb jetpack and sprint shoes take tens of thousands of bucks to acquire.

Now for the collection part. Yes, the cross breeding of slimes is interesting, but the fun easily perishes after couple of minutes. The price drop system even makes the efforts to obtain new slimes seem meaningless. When players want to obtain materials for crafting the game most certainly discourages versatility-breed one type of slimes with others so you can plant only one type of food and have maximum efficiency. The carnivorous slimes are not ideal to raise without herbivores because chicken breeding is just so inefficient.  

BTW, the extended ranches such as Viktor’s lab and the mercury ranch are synonyms for boredom. I spent about an hour on the single repeating task of spotting and chasing slimes, highly focused and almost shoved my face into the screen, in the end the game gave me nothing more than some land and thumb pain. “Oh but the new slimes.” YES there were new slimes, and YES there were special mechanisms, but you have access to them in the game level, meaning that if you wanna see them again you gotta chase after their a££ for almost no reward and almost no interaction. Makes me recall my girlfriend on bed, no matter what I do she lies there doing the same stuff. The saber-toothed slime is the only exception were you can take its crystals from the world and cross-breed it with the original slimes you have.

You can call me a hater, but most of the players in the comment section either only have played for less than ten hours or are masochistic (like I sometimes am) and have played for more than thirty hours.

I bought this looking for a cozy, dopamine-seeking, and low stress game with good vibes. I was not disappointed! In fact, the slimes are so high dopamine I convinced my partner to play - and he finished the game before I did!
While I am a completionist and worked to do all the things, there is no time gating where you will miss out on any content or need to rush. The graphics are great and the controls fairly smooth. All the slimes are insanely cute. Good luck picking your favorites ;)

My only real critique is that - like others have said - you get teleport systems and late game content a bit *too late*... like to the point where you might be done with the game, and there's no reason to keep going even though you get cool new things. Even with this, the game is amazingly fun, addicting, and chill.
I can't wait to play the sequel! <3

There's a lot to say about this game when it comes to being a cozy, zen experience. The exploration is excellent, the slimes are cute, the soundtrack is excellent, truly just a phenomenal experience for folks who like laid back exploration and farming games. Clearly it doesn't have a AAA budget, but every decision Monomi Park made in putting this game together was the right decision, and they used all the resources they had very efficiently. The graphics are simple, but beautiful with excellent art direction, for example.

Truly what sets this game apart from a lot of others in the genre, however, is how well it actually tells a story. You never meet another person, but getting messages from people you used to know, interfacing with other ranchers who are out here in the depths of space for their own reasons, finding logs left behind by the explorer who came before you--it asks a lot of interesting questions about why you're here, playing this game right now. And it explores those themes in ways that were truly surprising and welcome for me. It's very easy to ignore or miss the narrative threads scattered around the game, but if it interests you I highly encourage thoroughly reading everything you come across.

I'll be honest, I thought I'd like this game more than I did. Don't get me wrong, it's a good game, but it's definitely not what I thought going in.

I'm not the type who sees games like this as chill or relaxing. I'm the kind of psycho who stresses over every little thing in these sandboxy games. A buddy of mine once said I approach every task in Stardew Valley like someone is holding my entire family hostage, and honestly I can't argue. But that's a large part of the appeal of these kinda sims for me, refining and refining until I reach a state of equilibrium.

And that's the thing, I think they know about people like me. I think they had the kind of player I am in mind from the get-go. Because it feels like there are parts of this designed specifically to nudge people away from that style of play. And I don't even think that's necessarily a bad thing, I kinda respect it.

Normally, the way I approach these kinda games is to focus on one part of my sandbox until it's more-or-less hands off, then pivot to the next with the resources gained along the way. Obviously, gotta dip your toe in many areas on the side, but usually it's easy to do the bare minimum with side ventures until it's time to **optimize**. In Slime Rancher, that "hands off" point never comes, at least not until late-late game for even minor setups. Even a fully decked out corral with an autofeeder/autocollector needs pretty regular refilling/emptying, and because your ranch areas are pretty spread out, you have to do a lot of running back and forth to keep on top of everything and making sure the Quantum/Explosive slime crossbreeds you thought would be a good idea aren't quantum-tunneling out of their enclosure because the guy who thought he could play slime god forgot to get metaphysical lemons. Just as a hypothetical.

What I'm trying to get at is, no matter how much you try to hyperfocus on one thing, Slime Rancher says "Okay but what if everything lit on fire just sometimes. Bet you didn't think of that, Mr. Perfectionist." and as much as it drives me up the wall, I get it. No matter how much you upgrade your tech, and improve your technique, there's always this element of chaos. Many of this game's mechanics have something that makes them just slightly wonky, so you never quite lose that feeling of doing things a little messy. That it's okay to mess up sometimes, that you don't have to be flawless about everything. Anti-perfectionism.

Could I just be coping with the fact that I still suck ass and panic about everything after 30 hours of playing? Perhaps. But it's fun to analyze shit like this.

Anyway, game is solid, check it out if you don't mind getting a little messy.

I absolutely love this game. I owned the game on my PlayStation 4, but the game wasn't optimized correctly for that console. I recently got a new PC that I've been saving for a while and I can definitely say that it was worth the wait to play on something that could actually run it. 

I have been obsessed with this game for the better part of a week and I've done so many things and I'm already almost done with everything after a total play time of 24 Hours. Granted I already know what I'm doing so I the idea of what to get down and what to unlock. People who are knew to this game with have plenty of time to explore and find things on there own. Even after 24 hours of playtime I have a few things left and how I sped run the game basically means that there are going to be countless hours of playtime for those new.

This game is truly amazing with the different areas and mechanics it introduces slowly throughout the game. It doesn't feel rushed when introducing these either which makes progression feel like you're at the right place. This game allows you to go at your own pace so you never feel like you're behind. Just take your time and enjoy the scenery and music while you play. Even when you think you're done there is always something else to do. I have about 2 big things left for me to do on my own play through and even then something else that i haven't thought about yet might come up giving me more time do to the things I love in this amazing game. 

When I do end up finishing I can always transition to the second game which I hope has the same or even more content than this game has to introduce. I haven't played. Watched, or even done research on the game because I want to hype myself up about it and I'm truly excited to see what this next game has to offer.

I am a 49 yo mother, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single mother to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you were supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he helped me. Loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my husband had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.
Thank you <3

[h1]Comentario Analítico: "Slime Rancher"[/h1]

Slime Rancher es un relajante juego de granjas y aventuras en primera persona, totalmente carente de estrés al contar con tan pocas adversidades que incluso pueden desactivarse jugando en dificultad "Casual".

Artísticamente (Tanto en términos musicales como visuales) da todo de sí para sentirse tranquilizador, y su loop jugable es la constante dopamina nacida de comprar casillas o mejoras para generar más ingresos a invertir.

No es nada novedoso pero sí resulta entretenido; por otra parte la exploración es uno de sus peores aspectos. El constante ir y volver no sería tan incómodo si no fuera por los únicos 4 espacios disponibles en el inventario (Descartando el espacio para líquidos), por tanto apenas tengas 4 objetos distintos habrá que regresarse a pie todo el camino hasta casa.

El mapamundi no es de particular ayuda y las diferentes zonas no aportan una gran diferencia más allá del color del suelo y un par de assets. Son cosas que puedo entender y perdonar en un proyecto de bajos recursos, pero que de igual forma tienen su impacto en el producto final.

[b]¿En conclusión?[/b] Bonito, decente y entretenido.

Perfect Game #64, Slime Rancher.  Slime Rancher is a really cute and relaxing "farming" type game.  There is a story to be found, but it was never at the forefront.  The real meat is collecting the slimes and feeding them food to make money.  But with that money you can open areas to find more slimes, and then you can combine slimes to make combo slimes which produce more money.  It's an addicting loop, but the art style and mood of the game make it a really relaxing and enjoyable experience.

Slime Rancher is a highly addictive, charming, and colorful farming sim.  It's very hard not to like!  The gameplay loop is fairly simple (collect a slime, collect the food they like, grow the food, fuse slimes, upgrade stuff with your money from selling plonks) but is balances very well for an enjoyable and engaging experience.    Definitely worth a try, especially if you can get it on sale like I did!

Slime Rancher is a cozy farm-life simulator with an emphasis on exploration. There are charming environments, quaint characters, and relaxing puzzles.

It is probably the most family-friendly game in its category. There is a lot of pointing and aiming with first-person 3D controls, but basically no violence. There is a simulated daily cycle, but no time pressure. Most of the reading is optional, and the counting is very simple. So it is suitable for a kid just learning to read and compare numbers.

The progression in the original Slime Rancher is mostly based on collecting certain numbers of items, which can be found through exploration and cultivation. The sequel introduces more tiers of tools required to unlock more items which can be used to craft more tools.

I would recommend this game to everyone. It is a colourful, fun and engaging game with a great sense of exploration, adventure and discovery. These elements make Slime Rancher one of my favourite games. With both adventure and rush modes, the game offers different ways that you can play. Players also have the opportunity to create the ranch that best suits them. There are a plethora of plot spaces in order to accommodate for slimes, storage, water, crops and more. The story is fab and all of the locations that you can explore are well designed and beautiful. I completed the game in around 54 hours including all of the achievements, which is a good length for this game.

Beatrix LeBeau. A girl with a dream and a job that sends her 1,000 lightyears away from Earth to a planet called The Far, Far Range to become a Rancher of a strange, unusual, and surprisingly profitable species – Slimes. Take control of an old Ranch, fix her up, build your corrals to contain any interesting Slimes you may obtain after exploring this strange Island, and follow the clues and notes left behind from The Ranch’s former owner. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3032300254
7-40+ hours to complete; Slime Rancher is an Open-World Singleplayer Adventure game with a vibrant, cute, and colorful art style. There are a wide variety of Slimes you can capture and even more when you start dabbling in making your own type of Slime by mixing two together. The Island is big, beautiful, and for the most part, pretty fun to explore with many mysteries. Some cons I would like to bring up, is the incredibly short story mode; you can finish the game pretty quickly, and on accident if you’re good at exploring! Another thing is the game tends to give you access to useful items far too late; by the time I no longer needed to backtrack and had access to all the Slimes I needed to; I got teleporters. After I explored every inch of the island and found all it’s secrets, I finally got the Treasure Crackers needed to open all the previous inaccessible treasure chests discovered. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3029240899
While Slime Rancher is a really, really good game, I wish there were just some things it could have done better. Backtracking is very frequent, and finding all these neat treasure chests and having no way to open them during the initial exploration was kinda depressing. Regardless, I liked it, it’s a very good game that’s genuinely enjoyable and many people clearly love it too – considering it’s getting a movie adaptation. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3032300235

"Slime Rancher" is a survival and exploration game developed and published by Monomi Park. The game takes you to a world inhabited by colourful and cute monsters on a distant planet. Players try to develop their farm by collecting, cultivating and managing slimes.

Slime Collection and Breeding: The game contains different types and colours of slimes. You can catch slimes, bring them to your farm and breed them to obtain more rare and valuable species.

Exploration and World: The game takes place in a large open world with different biomes. Players can explore new areas, gather resources, and search for hidden areas.

Forage Farming and Resource Management: You will need to grow feed according to the needs of the slides. Also collecting and processing resources is important to develop your farm.

Equipment and Research: The game offers various equipment and upgrades. You can obtain new tools and abilities through research.

Graphics and Style: "Slime Rancher" stands out with colourful and cute graphics. The design of the slides and the world provides players with a fun experience.

Community and Mods: The game is popular among players and has a mod community. Mods can help you personalise the experience of the game.

Community and Reviews: "Slime Rancher" has received generally positive reviews among players and critics. The cute graphics, exploration elements, and slime farming mechanics are appreciated by players, while some players may criticise the repetitive aspects of the game or some aspects of the gameplay.

Development and Publisher: Monomi Park is the developer and publisher of the game. The game is supported by regular updates and content additions.

Conclusion: "Slime Rancher" offers a fun and relaxing survival and farming experience. Cute slides, a large open world and various mechanics create a game world that draws players in. If you are looking for a farming and exploration game with colourful and cute graphics, "Slime Rancher" can offer you an enjoyable experience. Check out the game's community and reviews to see if the game is right for you.

Embracing the Slime-filled Adventure: Exploring the Charms of Slime Rancher

Rating: ★★★★☆ (4/5)

Slime Rancher invites players to embark on a delightful and colorful journey to a distant world teeming with adorable, gelatinous creatures. With its charming visuals, engaging gameplay mechanics, and the allure of ranching and nurturing slimes, the game offers a unique and endearing experience that captures the hearts of players young and old.

The visual design of Slime Rancher is a whimsical feast for the eyes, presenting players with a vibrant and imaginative world where slimes come in all shapes, sizes, and colors. The game's cartoonish style adds to the charm, creating an atmosphere that is both lively and delightful.

At its core, Slime Rancher combines elements of ranch management, exploration, and creature collection. Players take on the role of a "slime rancher," capturing and raising slimes on their very own ranch. The mechanics are accessible, with players collecting and feeding slimes to harvest valuable resources known as "plorts."

The joy of discovery is a standout feature, as players explore new environments, encounter different types of slimes, and uncover the secrets of the world. The sense of exploration and the thrill of finding new and rare slimes create an engaging sense of curiosity.

The game's blend of ranching and resource management mechanics adds depth to the gameplay. Players must balance their ranch's ecosystem, feed slimes the right food to produce valuable plorts, and upgrade their facilities to optimize their ranching operation.

However, the game's relatively relaxed pace and lack of intense challenges might not resonate with players seeking more action-oriented experiences. Slime Rancher leans more towards a casual and laid-back gameplay style.

The game's learning curve and mechanics might require some time for new players to grasp. While the initial stages are accessible, mastering the intricacies of ranch management and resource optimization could take a while.

In conclusion, Slime Rancher offers a charming and heartwarming adventure that invites players to embrace the world of adorable slimes and the joy of ranching. Its whimsical visuals, engaging mechanics, and the allure of discovery create an experience that is both relaxing and endearing. While its casual pace and lack of intense challenges might not appeal to everyone, those who appreciate a light-hearted and colorful world filled with delightful creatures will find themselves immersed in the captivating ranching journey of Slime Rancher, where every slime and plort hold the promise of a vibrant and gelatinous escapade.

I've had slime rancher for a while now and I'd have to say I've enjoyed my time playing. Upon starting up the game it can be overwhelming for the sheer amount of slime's you'll come across and how dig the open world is. I've found it to be relaxing at times, however this game is not all sunshine and rainbows, you do a lot of grinding in this game
Finding the portals to travel back between home and the different worlds, trying to find map pieces and keys to open new sections is time consuming just because the maps are so big the creators like to hide things in all the nooks are cranny's of the game. 
Overall the game is enjoyable, you see some funky stuff go on and the variety of slime's keep your attention and you can find a few challenges here and there to keep it interesting.

During one of the most stressful periods of my life, I bought this game on the Xbox. It's so peaceful, so addicting. It was the perfect game to fall back on whenever I felt stress. The slimes are adorable, and the environments are absolutely stunning, particularly those in the late game. And I mean the bee drones are in their own tier when it comes to adorableness.

For now, I'd say I recommend purchasing Slime Rancher over Slime Rancher 2 as the latter still seems to be very early in its lifetime and has a lot less content than you'll find in this game.

A super fun and relaxingly pleasurable gaming experience. If you are looking for something cute and stress free then this is absolutely the game for you. My favourite aspect is definitely the unique gameplay and mechanics. The game runs smoothly and looks great.

It may not be abundant with features but there are certainly enough, sufficiently well placed, to where the game keeps you engaged. The aim of the game is to collect different types of slimes to where there drops will provide different quantities of money depending on the rarity (how far the slime is in the games progression system) of the slime. You can combine slimes to make collecting their drops more efficient and the exploration and progression system are fantastic. 

Shouldn't take you longer than 20 hours to complete the game but definitely worth the play. Would recommend to anyone who enjoys casual gameplay and cute slimes. Forgot to mention the soundtrack is really fitting :)

Slime Rancher is a carefree and (mostly) stress-free farm management game that blends exploration and farming in a seamless manner, creating an addictive gameplay loop which is mostly driven by the player's curiosity.

[list]
[*][b]Farming[/b]
[/list]
A lot of your time will be spent farming, and while it's not a complicated system at all, mostly just asking of the players that they take the slimes' diets into account, there are a plethora of interesting tools that make this aspect of the game more efficient and/or automated, I found this aspect of SR to be welcoming to both casual players and the min-maxers. 

[list]
[*][b]Exploration[/b]
[/list]
By exploring you find new slimes and crops (and meat) for your farm, there are a lot of secret areas and chest to be found if the player decides to go off the beaten path and as a result each discovery feels rewarding, everything you find is useful in one way or another. 
There are also a number of locked doors that lead to new areas giving the player great motivation to find the keys that eventually open them, finally setting foot in a new part of the map feels great!
Although very different games, I felt that SR's exploration sometimes gave off Metroid Prime vibes in its approach, there are a couple of sequence breaks too if you're into that ;)

Finding something new is exciting, throughout the whole first playthrough with each new discovery it left me guessing "what's next?" and thinking "that's so cool!".

[list]
[*][b]Progression[/b]
[/list]
The game's systems effortlessly flow into each other and progression is handled so that both farming and exploration reward the players with tools that help with one aspect or the other, so that they can either farm or explore more efficiently. Progress in one of the two aspects eventually means progress in the other. Mostly.

I found that SR lacked a reason to keep the player playing after having expolored all the map.
Other than unlocking all the achievements (which is fun), you'll find that way after the credits roll there will still be a lot of stuff left to unlock that doesn't really serve much of a purpose as there is no particular goal anymore. I also didn't agree with the choice to lock the ability to open chests behind unlocking the [spoiler]Laboratory[/spoiler] since I think finding them should be enough to earn the player the reward, I suggest you unlock it as early as you can so that you don't finish the game with most chests unopened, it can easily happen.

In other words, while really really good until the credits roll, the synergy between farming and exploration is lacking in the endgame, curiosity won't be a drive anymore since there will be nothing left to explore even if there are still a lot of things to unlock but not a lot of reasons to use them.

[list]
[*][b]Visuals & Sound[/b]
[/list]
Visuals are not groundbreaking in themselves, especially when it comes to UI, art direction however is pretty neat! Environments are easily recognizable even without looking at the map, and the different slimes (and their "fusions") look funny and adorable, and even threatening sometimes. Unfortunately performance on a 1050 (which isn't some incredible GPU, I know) was quite lacking even if it never even came close to unplayable, there were framerate drops and stutters all over the place, optimization isn't the best and SR should run fine on this hardware as do many other more graphically demanding games.

Soundtrack is catchy and upbeat mostly, there are a couple pieces that stand out as more melancholic and grandiose near the end and those are great too, sound is really satisfying when shooting stuff into the market board (selling) and in a game like this that's the best you can ask for.

[list]
[*][b]Final thoughts[/b]
[/list]
Slime Rancher is definitely a game worth playing if you're looking for a colorful fun farming game that's very exploration driven and doesn't hold your hand but is accessible nonetheless, not having a time limit makes it so that it's never particularly stressful. It's enjoyable on multiple levels making it a lot of fun for both experienced and unexperienced players.

This is such a cute game! I loved collecting each of the slimes and exploring each new area. I will definitely be buying Slime Rancher 2!

My only problem is that after 30 hours, I'd reached every area and collected every type of slime and felt that there wasn't much to do after that. There are the minigames where you can unlock more areas to house more slimes or grow veggies but I personally didn't feel the need for so much space. Maybe the game isn't meant to be played for much more than that, I couldn't say, but I personally felt I'd accomplished everything I wanted to do after the 30 hour mark.

Very minor con there, but overall it's a fantastic game! Such a cute art style, I love that each slime design was created with care and love. I loved finding each one and trying out different combinations to get different largos. There was always excitement and wonder whenever I found new slime types and I instantly wanted to catch them. The music is relaxing and it's got such a bubbly, happy feeling to it. Definitely recommend! Slime Rancher is a blast!

A Comfy Slime-filled Adventure!

Slime Rancher is an adorable and cozy game that will warm your heart. The cute, slimy creatures and charming art style create a delightful atmosphere that makes playing it a joy. With the freedom to explore and collect various slimes, it's a truly relaxing and comfy experience. If you're looking for a game to unwind and enjoy the cuteness, Slime Rancher is the perfect choice!

It's visually pleasing and it's easy to know what to do most of the time, sometimes it's tricky finding where to go though. It's enjoyable in the aspect where you get to feed and clean up after slimes, farm and also breed chickens. I enjoyed how much there was to do and explore and all the new things you'd unlock randomly as you progressed through the game. It's alltogether enjoyable and a great way to waste time.

this game is a favorite. It's cute and cozy and exciting when playing on adventure mode. I am a gamer with a short attention span so sitting down and playing something is really hard for me. but i spent 14 hours on this game in the past two weeks which means I really like it bc I normally only have about an hour to three hours on average records. 10/10 would recommend especially for cozy gamers

Slime Rancher is a cozy first-person farming adventure game following the tale of a young rancher named Beatrix LeBeau who sets out a thousand light years away from Earth on an alien planet called the Far, Far Range, where she tries to make a living wrangling slimes. You will collect tons of colorful and unique slimes with a vacpack to then feed them in order to obtain plorts, a valuable bi-product that comes from each slime that you can then sell on the plort market for money in order to purchase new things for your ranch. You can grow crops, harvest resources, trade with other ranchers, and raise chickadoos to feed your slimes along with building corrals for them. You can also create cool gadgets, decorations, and upgrades for your vacpack as well as your ranch, while also exploring the secrets and dangers of this mysterious planet. It has a very relaxing soundtrack with a charming story. The gameplay is incredibly fun, chill, and satisfying, I cannot recommend it enough.

*EDIT: I can't stop thinking about the game even 3 years after first playing it. I had to buy the soundtracks just for someone to get more of my money. In an unexplainable way, the main narrative of the game just resonates with me. The peacefulness and existential questions make me endlessly sad and thoughtful.

God I love this game! I played it first on the xbox years ago, and have been feeling nostalgic to the peaceful and cute atmosphere of the game. Purchasing it again was an amazing choice. 9/10.

The game can be "beat" in roughly 8 hours of work and exploration. It is very simple in mechanics and the way to the end; however, new players will likely explore many areas and spend their keys on things that don't progress to the end. 

The story of the game comes in letters from your SO and notes placed around the map by the ranches previous owner. The dialogue from the previous owner is deep, sad, and wholly relatable.

The only downside I see to the game is it can feel a bit grindy in the end. Once you finish the main exploration and unlock the map, the end is just collecting as much money and plorts as possible to unlock toys and customization of your ranch. I wish there was slightly more automation, or at least not so much building contraptions for the lab. That being said, it is completely optional and provides nothing to the game than if you want to 100% your customization and prettiness.

Slime Rancher, a delightful and heartwarming video game developed by Monomi Park, is a whimsical masterpiece that takes players on an enchanting journey of joy and discovery. With its captivating visuals, charming characters, and a world teeming with adorable slimes, this game has earned its place as a true wholesome gem in the gaming world.

One of the standout features of Slime Rancher is its vibrant and visually stunning world. The Far, Far Range, the game's setting, is a magical place filled with lush landscapes, colorful flora, and the cutest, squishiest slimes you'll ever encounter. The attention to detail is remarkable, and exploring this captivating environment is an absolute pleasure. Each area is distinct and has its own unique charm, making the game feel alive and full of wonder.

But what truly sets Slime Rancher apart is its emphasis on positivity and nurturing. As a player, you step into the shoes of Beatrix LeBeau, a young, spirited rancher who embarks on a journey to build her own slime ranch. Your task is to care for and raise various species of slimes, feed them, collect their plorts (the valuable resources they produce), and create a thriving ranch. The game's mechanics are intuitive and accessible, allowing players of all ages to enjoy the experience.

The slimes themselves are undeniably the stars of the show. From the adorable pink slimes that greet you at the beginning to the quirky, specialized slimes that inhabit later areas, each one has its own distinct personality. It's impossible not to fall in love with their playful antics and endearing behaviors. The sound design and animation further enhance their charm, making every interaction a delightful experience.

The gameplay loop in Slime Rancher is addictive and rewarding. You'll find yourself constantly exploring, discovering new slimes, and expanding your ranch with new corrals, gardens, and gadgets. The progression feels natural, allowing you to unlock new areas and abilities at a comfortable pace. The game strikes a perfect balance between relaxation and challenge, making it suitable for both casual and more dedicated players.

Beyond the ranching mechanics, Slime Rancher offers a deep sense of exploration and discovery. Throughout the game, you'll stumble upon hidden secrets, uncover lore, and encounter intriguing characters. The world-building is exceptional, leaving you with a sense of awe and curiosity. The developers have crafted a rich and immersive universe that invites you to lose yourself in its captivating narrative.

Slime Rancher is more than just a game; it's an experience that evokes pure joy and positivity. Its charming aesthetics, delightful gameplay, and heartfelt themes make it a true masterpiece of wholesome entertainment. Whether you're a seasoned gamer or new to the world of video games, Slime Rancher is an absolute must-play. It will warm your heart, bring a smile to your face, and remind you of the simple pleasures that can be found in the most unexpected places.

If you are a fan of cute animals and collecting things, this game is for you! In Slime Rancher, you collect spunky but adorable creatures (known as slimes) and put them in your ranch. When you feed one of these slimes, they produce plorts. Plorts are sold through the Plort Market, which is a way that people from planet Earth exchange currency (Newbucks) for slimes plorts. The rarer the slimes, the higher the price! But, if you sell a lot of the rare plorts at a time, the next day the price of them will drop. 
This game is super fun!

Slime Rancher, developed by Monomi Park, is a delightful and addictive indie game that combines elements of farming, exploration, and adorable creatures. With its charming visuals, addictive gameplay, and a world brimming with lovable slimes, Slime Rancher offers a unique and captivating experience that will leave players enchanted.

One of the standout features of Slime Rancher is its whimsical and vibrant art style. The game's colorful and cartoonish visuals create a cheerful atmosphere that is both visually appealing and relaxing. The slimes themselves are utterly adorable, each with their own distinct appearances and behaviors. From the bouncy pink slimes to the fiery rock slimes, encountering and collecting these charming creatures is an absolute joy.

The core gameplay revolves around managing a slime ranch on the distant Far, Far Range. As Beatrix LeBeau, players embark on a journey to collect and care for various types of slimes. The ranch requires careful planning, from building corrals and gardens to feed the slimes, to expanding and upgrading the facilities. The game strikes a perfect balance between simplicity and depth, making it accessible for players of all ages, yet offering enough complexity to keep them engaged.

Exploration is a key aspect of Slime Rancher. Venturing into different areas of the Far, Far Range unveils new slimes, resources, and secrets. Discovering hidden caves or rare slimes adds a sense of adventure and accomplishment. The world feels expansive, with each area offering unique landscapes and challenges to overcome.

One of the game's most enjoyable mechanics is slime wrangling. Players must learn the behavior and preferences of different slimes, carefully capturing them and ensuring they are well-fed and content. Mixing different types of slimes can lead to lucrative plorts, which serve as the game's currency. Experimenting with slime combinations adds a layer of strategy and discovery.

Slime Rancher's progression system is well-balanced, providing a steady stream of new abilities, upgrades, and areas to explore. As you unlock new gadgets and improvements, such as jetpacks or teleporters, the gameplay becomes more dynamic and exciting. The sense of growth and accomplishment keeps players motivated and eager to continue their ranching adventures.

While Slime Rancher is a delightful and addictive experience, it does have a few minor drawbacks. The game's objectives can become repetitive over time, and some players may desire more complex challenges or additional activities to keep them engaged in the long run. However, the developers have consistently released updates and free content expansions, adding new features and gameplay elements to keep the experience fresh.

In conclusion, Slime Rancher is a charming and captivating game that will warm the hearts of players of all ages. Its delightful visuals, addictive gameplay mechanics, and lovable slimes make it a joy to play. Whether you're tending to your ranch, exploring the vibrant world, or simply enjoying the adorable antics of the slimes, Slime Rancher offers a whimsical and relaxing escape that will leave you with a smile on your face.

Life had always been a whirlwind, filled with responsibilities that often left little room for relaxation. But amidst the chaos, there was always my sanctuary: Slime Rancher. The game offered a blissful oasis where I could forget life's burdens and immerse myself in the vibrant world of adorable, bouncing slimes.

However, as fate would have it, my real-life obligations began to encroach upon the time I had set aside for Slime Rancher. Endless deadlines, familial responsibilities, and unexpected challenges took precedence, leaving the slimes abandoned on the virtual range.

Days turned into weeks, and the sound of playful slime giggles slowly faded away. Yet, within the realm of my overwhelming reality, a void formed, longing for the companionship of those squishy creatures. I yearned to return to the ranch, to the innocence and simplicity that only existed in the embrace of digital worlds.

Finally, a moment of clarity emerged amidst the chaos. I realized that taking a break from the turbulence of my daily life was essential for both my mental rejuvenation and happiness. Slime Rancher served as a gentle reminder of the importance of self-care and the beauty of simplicity—lessons I had momentarily forgotten.

With renewed determination, I re-entered the virtual realm of Slime Rancher, greeted by the familiar melodies of cheerful slimes. Their radiant smiles radiated warmth, serving as a beacon of solace and positivity. In their presence, I found solace once again, reminded that even amidst the unpredictable nature of existence, there will always be joy waiting to be rediscovered.

Slime Rancher… where do I even begin?

Well, at the beginning I guess.

Slime Rancher is a very chill exploration and life sim ranching game. We play as Beatrix LeBeau, a rancher who moves from Earth to The Far, Far Range to begin her life as a “slime rancher” (Hey, that’s the name of the game!)

First thing you see after the opening text of the game is the beautiful art style. This game is up there with my favourite game art styles, such as Team Fortress 2 and Hollow Knight. It is such a beautiful, cheery and bubbly style that strikes the perfect balance of not too bright and not too toned down. You feel a sense of comfort and safety here, even though the place is completely brand new.

We start out in our ranch, previously owned by Hobson Twilligers, in a pretty bad state, and learn how the basics of the game. How to use our Vacpack, feeding slimes and keeping them. Not too long after that, we venture out into the world, our first location. You’ll come back to your ranch eventually and it has 4 distinct locations to unlock. The Lab, which we’ll get to later, The Grotto and The Overgrowth, themed expansions for your ranch, and The Docks which is also another (although, smaller) expansion.

I’ll just be giving a general overview of locations because I don’t want to spoil them if you do play the game.

The Dry, Dry Reef. Not my personal favourite, but it holds a place in my heart. A mainly orange mountainous area full of nooks and crannies to explore and a great first area for newcomers to learn in. What once was a reef is now a land area where you’ll find many slimes and spend most of your time until you find your first Gordo and Slime Key.

With a Slime Key, you can open up two new areas: The Indigo Quarry, or my second personal favourite, The Moss Blanket.

The Indigo Quarry is, well, a quarry like area, with many little island-like areas to go between and explore, with beautiful hexagonal crystals around everywhere giving The Indigo Quarry the distinct look it has which you’ll find no where else, among many caves to explore. There is also a way to get to the Ash Isle in The Indigo Quarry, which is a very cool volcanic area.

The Moss Blanket is a jungle like area, and it is huge with it split into two distinct areas: The main land and the smaller island congregation. The area is vibrant and full of colour while not overdoing it, full of massive trees, flowers, vines, oversized logs and vines.

Both these areas have Slime Key doors which lead you to The Ancient Ruins Courtyard. A utterly HUGE door with slime statues all around where you must give the statue the corresponding plort to open the door, and then brings you to my personal favourite area in the game…

The Ancient Ruins. Everything about this area is just amazing, the funny doors, the funny echoes, the soundtrack, the visuals, the slimes, the fruits… It is all perfect. Makes an area that seems cliché and dingy feel very unique. This area houses the portal to the last area in the game too, which is:

The Glass Desert. One of the most unique areas in the game, and I will only say it houses the ending to the game.

You have the Range Exchange on your ranch, a way to trade with people across The Far, Far Range. Some of these people will give you opportunities to help them and work with them if you do enough of these.

Mochi Miles will ask you to help her with obtaining the elusive Quicksilver Slime plorts, which is a fun minigame where you shoot electric balls at them to get the plorts. Finish it, and you’ll get cool upgrades and you’ll be allowed to use the plots at Mochi’s Manor.

Ogden Ortiz will ask you to get his favourite plant, the Kookadoba, from a place called “The Wilds” full of thought to be extinct Saber Slimes, which of course are feral. Ogden will give you upgrades for your garden and allow you to use the plots at Ogden’s Retreat if you finish the amount he requests.

Viktor Humphries will ask you to help him to debug his “Slimeulation”. This is possibly one of the best help requests in the game, where you are asked to traverse an increasingly unstable Slimeulation in order to collect Glitch Slimes for bug reports. In exchange for finishing, he’ll give you cool new Slime Science gadgets and, of course, the plots in his lab.

Wait, Slime Science? Yep! This game has a pretty basic but fleshed out science system, and a fun one at that. Put drills, apiaries and pumps all around the world and depending where you put them, you’ll get different items. Varying levels of extractors, with the best being a 7Zee Rewards Club reward, which we’ll get to soon. You can craft all kinds of cool stuff at the previously aforementioned lab, whether it be stupid fashion pods and games, drones, more extractors, decorations, or useful items, there is a lot. Most of these blueprints are found through treasure pods around The Far, Far Range.

Through the upgrade station at your ranch (which allows you to buy a jetpack by the way, amazing!) Through the 7Zee Rewards Club, you can earn Treasure Cracker upgrades, which allow you to start opening treasure pods. Pretty neat, huh?

Alright, what the hell is the 7Zee Rewards Club? Pretty simple. A small thing where you pay a sum of money to get rewards, which stops at level 28. Not that exciting but it unlocks a cooler looking ranch.

To pair with the art, the soundtrack to this game is phenomenal. It can be chaotic, calming or spooky and still sound like Slime Rancher. Also, there’s a track for each location for day and night, and the night tracks are usually a lot more calm and chill, with the day tracks being upbeat and a bit rowdy. Also, the end credits song is very emotional. Very few games make me cry, but the end credits did it for me.

All this, and I forgot to talk about the slimes! Many different types, all with different diets (meat, fruit, veggie, water, ash) different little things they do, and different ways to keep them, but there’s one thing they all have in common: they’re all darn cute.

I’ve played this game since the early access, and this game holds a very special place in my heart. While it doesn’t get updates anymore, and probably won’t considering Slime Rancher 2 is being developed now, it got me through rough times and it has to be my favourite game of all time. 

Also, the Tabby Slime is amazing, I mean, just look at that little boop it does!

If you read all of this, thank you, and if you buy the game, I hope you enjoy it as much as I did.

Good game, I enjoy farming games but sometimes feel held back by slow movement or progression, but Slime Rancher’s movement and fun environments allowed me to parkour and jet pack around and so I never felt too slow or inefficient. For me, Slime Rancher allowed me to progress at my own pace, which I really like because other farming games are usually limited in freedom, while you can find/make shortcuts in Slime Rancher. But even if you are extra efficient and fast, Slime rancher still has a nice progression curve, and I think it’s the perfect combination for a farming game.

Completionist info at the bottom. Mild spoilers in this review. Rating 9/10

Slime Rancher is an adorable farming/adventure sim where your main goal is to find every type of slime, establish a corral for them on your farm, and feed them regularly in order to grow your profits. The main gameplay loop is centered around exploration. The homestead that you begin with is fairly self-sufficient from the get-go and the player is left free to explore the various connected islands within the game, gathering foods, collectables, and, most importantly, all varieties of slimes along the way.

The art style of this game is fantastic. In fact, the entire atmosphere of the game perfectly encapsulates that cozy-game spirit that so many games struggle to find. The music is pleasant, the landscapes are beautiful, and the slimes are cute. Also, importantly, there is nothing scary in this game. Sure, there are enemies, but they are slow-moving, bad at attacking, and also cute in their own ugly way. If atmosphere alone made a game great, then Slime Rancher would be one of the best.

The gameplay is, overall, great. The focus on exploration that this game has lends itself well to the gameplay loop which it establishes. By that I mean that it would boring if all you did in this game was tend to your slimes on your farm. The mechanics are not complex enough to warrant that, but they aren’t supposed to be. The player is supposed to be out exploring the majority of the time, with only an hour or so here and there at the farm, mostly spent reconfiguring your various slimes in different corrals, trying out different slime fusions, and expanding into newly purchased locations. Once everything is set up again, off you go into the wild. I don’t mean to suggest, however, that the slime ranch is boring. I, for one, found a great deal of enjoyment in rearranging my slimes and making my farm as efficient as possible. But this is not entirely necessary. The complexity is there, but only if the player has a self-imposed inclination towards efficiency.

The exploration in Slime Rancher is great. The movement takes a bit of getting used to, but once one is accustomed to it, the movement feels great. It is fast and dynamic, allowing the player to sprint quite quickly and for a long period of time (once upgrades are purchased). The game also allows the player access to just about anywhere on the map, aided by the handy jetpack. In Slime Rancher, out-of-bounds doesn’t really exist. One of my first, great moments with this game was when I realized that the game allowed me to walk on top of cliffs which had heretofore acted only as walls. Then, after I found an item on the cliff, I realized that I wasn’t just allowed to be up there, but I was supposed to be. Freedom is a great feeling which many games don’t allow the player due to various factors, primarily technical limitations, but Slime Rancher avoids these restrictions, instead opting for total freedom for the player to go wherever they would like.

However, the game isn’t perfect. My main complaint regards the inventory system which limits the player to only four different types of items. At first, this system works great and, I imagine, as intended. By limiting the player to four items, you are constantly returning to the ranch to unload and are thereby given a reason to return, check up on your slimes, and do other rancherly duties. But as the game progresses and the ranch becomes harder and harder to return to, this limitation becomes more and more tedious. Again, at first, this annoyance is ameliorated by the ability to construct teleporters, which allow the player a host of new movement options, connecting together previously disconnected parts of the world, but where the cracks really begin to show is with the slime science system.

I like the slime science system. It adds a great level of complexity to the game without being obtrusive. It allows the player such things as automation and about a hundred other timesavers. But, the resources that you need for slime science are in hard to reach places and, also, multitudinous. With the strict limit of four different inventory slots, it becomes very difficult to harvest your slime science extractors (drills, pumps, and apiaries). Each one of these can spit out three or four different items and, if trying to harvest multiple types, your inventory will quickly be at full capacity. What this leads to is numerous trips back and forth to the ranch just to pick items up off the ground. Eventually, yes, there are ways around this. The player can place Warp Depots every time they harvest their extractors, but the whole system is clunky to manage.

Still, even though I have gone on about it, this problem, and any others the game may have, are little more than a momentary inconvenience. Slime Rancher is still a great game. Even if it has a couple rough edges, a bit too much repetition, and a little too much disconnectedness between its DLC areas (Mochi’s Manor, Ogden’s Retreat, etc. . . ), it makes up for these flaws with its addictive gameplay loop, adorable design, and well-thought out system of slime fusions which give the player endless combinations to try. It is a farming-sim game with little farming, a lot of exploring, and nothing at all which breaks the cozy atmosphere. A great experience and a great time.


Completionist Information: (Difficulty – 5/10)(Fun – 7/10)(Time: 25-35 hours)

Slime Rancher has few difficult achievements. You will have to do everything in the game, catch every slime, go to every location, and deep dive into slime science and all that it entails, but none of this is challenging or overly time consuming. The game also has a story, which while it can be mostly ignored, needs to be completed for achievements. However, this task should be easily completable during normal gameplay.

The hardest achievements in the game are those relating to Rush Mode, a secondary mode which you will be required to play through where the player is given a time limit to collect as much money as possible. There are some nuances and a guide is recommended, but I was able to beat the challenge on my first attempt without too much trouble and maybe a half hour of planning. 

Overall, a fun game to complete as completion mainly consists of beating the game fully. As the gameplay is fun, I thought completing the game was fun also.

Slime Rancher was unexpectedly awesome for me. I didn't see myself as a person to go around farming slimes, but I loved the art and sound effects.
It didn't look like that much fun while watching streamers play it, but after getting it anyway I had a blast.

Not much thought required, savegames are optional (not much stuff goes wrong), and you can play at your own pace, trying to get everything perfect first try, or muddle on through. When stuff goes wrong, it usually involves slimes being funny, and then it's more fun to make the slimes behave than to reload a savegame.

This game is better even than Slime Rancher 2 (which I haven't played), because it comes with a native LINUX build (engine is Unity3D), which - as seems to be the norm with Unity3d - runs flawlessly on Linux. Even with a 10+yo OpenGL 4.3 AMD graphics card.
So the resource requirements are low, and the fun factor is high. Loved it.
It's only downside is, it's singleplayer only.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Tarr slimes, despite their voracious appetite for consuming other slimes, possess an undeniable charm and visual appeal. The amalgamation of black with rainbow-like colors exhibited by the tarr slimes presents an alluring aesthetic that could make them fascinating companions if their predatory behavior were absent. Imagining them as slime pets, with their striking and vibrant appearance, elicits a sense of wonder and delight. However, it is important to acknowledge that the game's design intentionally portrays tarr slimes as a threat, contributing to the gameplay dynamics and balance. Nevertheless, the idea of keeping a tarr slime as a pet, solely for its captivating visual qualities, highlights the imaginative possibilities that arise from the game's unique world and creature designs.

Slime Rancher is a super cute and charming game that falls into the "farming sim" or "monster collector" genre. You can fully automate your ranch using research and slime "plorts", and the designs of the slimes are adorable and creative. It's a relaxing and enjoyable experience that allows you to see your progress on the ranch. While the story is more of an assortment of letters and is somewhat disconnected from the gameplay, it doesn't diminish the overall enjoyment. The in-game listing of achievements is a convenient feature, eliminating the need to exit the game to track progress. Some achievements, particularly the rush mode ones, can be challenging but rewarding. If you're looking for a delightful break from your daily routine and love cute creatures, Slime Rancher is a must-play game in the farming sim genre.

Slime Rancher is an adventure game which the player gets to explore vast world of Far, Far Range, flourishing with beautiful landscapes and cute slimes. You get to make your own slime ranch where you feed the slimes, get their plorts and make money with it. As you progress, you have so much to do, such as visiting NPC worlds, finding pods spread all around the map and making gadgets in the laboratory. Slime Rancher is packed with chill and relaxing contents that you can enjoy whenever you feel bad, tired or bored. I strongly recommend this game as it not just having everything I mentioned, but absolutely astounding music and great storyline too. It is such a good game to relax, so please have a try on it.

I bought Slime Rancher a long time ago to bridge times between playing Stardew Valley, but never played it until recently. Turns out it's perfect as a game to fill some time between finding other games to play. 

The simplicity can sometimes be frustrating. I wish there was more to do, and I wish there was the ability to expand a bit. There's very little by way of artistic freedom; you don't get to choose the layout of your "farm" and everything looks the same. Exploring can also be a chore. "Fast Travel" isn't unlocked until very late game, and by that time it's not worth it because there's no reason to continue exploring. 

That being said, I still enjoyed it. It's no Stardew, but it temporarily scratches the same itch.

[h1]Slime Rancher[/h1]
Slime Rancher [b]holds a special place in my heart[/b] as my all-time favorite game. Its delightful world, endearing characters, and addictive gameplay have enchanted me from the very beginning. This charming gem has a way of whisking players away into a whimsical universe where slimes reign supreme, and the joy of exploration knows no bounds.

One of the most captivating aspects of Slime Rancher is its vibrant and imaginative setting. The Far, Far Range is a stunning and colorful landscape filled with unique and adorable slimes of all shapes, sizes, and personalities. From the mischievous Tabby Slimes to the adorable and bouncy Phosphor Slimes, every encounter with these gelatinous creatures is a source of wonder and delight. The attention to detail in the game's art style is remarkable, with lush environments and cleverly designed structures that bring the world to life.

The gameplay in Slime Rancher is addictively satisfying. As a slime rancher, your mission is to capture slimes, nurture them, and collect their precious plorts. The mechanics of feeding and corralling these squishy critters are simple to grasp but offer depth and complexity as you dive deeper into the game. The management aspect of the ranch, from building new structures to upgrading equipment, provides a sense of progression and constant discovery. With each new slime species discovered, you'll find yourself eager to expand your ranch and uncover the secrets hidden within the Far, Far Range.

One of the standout features of Slime Rancher is its emphasis on exploration and discovery. The world is teeming with hidden treasures, secret areas, and elusive slime types waiting to be found. Venturing into unexplored territories and stumbling upon rare slimes or hidden resources is an exhilarating experience that rewards curiosity and perseverance. The feeling of stumbling upon a new discovery or unlocking a previously inaccessible area is incredibly rewarding and fuels the desire to continue exploring every nook and cranny of the Far, Far Range.

Beyond its captivating gameplay, Slime Rancher also boasts a heartwarming narrative that adds depth to the overall experience. As you progress through the game, you'll uncover the mysteries of the world and encounter memorable characters who bring the story to life. The subtle messages of friendship, perseverance, and the importance of preserving nature are beautifully woven into the game's narrative, creating an emotionally resonant experience that goes beyond mere gameplay mechanics.

Lastly, the developers of Slime Rancher have consistently supported the game with updates and additions, demonstrating their commitment to the community and the longevity of the game. Their dedication to listening to player feedback and implementing new features has fostered an active and passionate community that continues to thrive.

In conclusion, Slime Rancher is a captivating and charming adventure that has captured the hearts of players around the world, including mine. Its vibrant world, addictive gameplay, and memorable characters make it an unforgettable experience that I keep returning to time and time again. Whether you're a fan of exploration, adorable creatures, or simply seeking a game that exudes joy and wonder, Slime Rancher is an absolute must-play. Prepare to be enchanted by its whimsical charm and embark on a journey that will leave you with a permanent smile on your face.

I waited until I had fully immersed myself into the world of Slime Rancher before writing my review, but I think it's finally time to give my full thoughts.

-Gameplay- 10/10
Slime Rancher, from the beginning, offers you an adventure in the vast area called the Far, Far Range, where, though never in person, you meet other ranchers that have destined their life to this calling themselves. Though simple mechanics, it offers a beautiful sense of calming loneliness.
You learn to ranch slimes, market off of their plorts, advance your gardens and coops, as well as corrals.
If wanted you can also utilize the Range Exchange, where you can help previously aforementioned ranchers with things they're lacking, in return you get a reward, whether it be money, plorts, fruit and veggies, or different assorted chickens, they always pay you back.
As the game progresses you help certain Ranchers with things that have caused them problems, or just mean a great deal. I won't spoil who you help, as I'd love for you to see it for yourself.
You can also keep in check with someone back on Earth through Emails, as well as the Ranchers, or the 7ZEE Rewards Program(Sign up for it, don't miss out).
Emails are useful in many different ways and open up the second part of my review, the story.

-The Story- 10/10
One of the main people you get emails from is someone back on Earth named Casey. It reveals things of the character you play as, who they are, and their values. It makes you feel as if you're on a personal connection with the character.
Another character you get to grow a personal connection with is Hobson, someone who you never see in person yet you learn every step of his beautiful life on this ranch you now own through markers he left on his leave.
I cry easily, so take this lightly if you'd like, but reading the end of Hobson's journey absolutely made me cry. Happy tears of course, I loved finally knowing peace on how he ended his journey just to start it again, it was so utterly beautiful. Just like the graphics, which I will get onto now.

-The Graphics and their Cleanliness.- 10/10
With some games, people with laptops may not always be able to play due to the demanding graphics, even on their lowest setting, and then sometimes if you lower the settings of a game, you can't even recognize the game you're playing.
I can rightfully say that Slime Rancher had mastered the constant of their graphics. You never feel out of sense, never feel like you're missing out, and it's still the same beautiful game. Seriously, the Mosaic slimes are still GORGEOUS on the lowest of graphics, applause to the team on this one.

-My Final Thoughts.-
Slime Rancher is an adventure I'd never want anyone else to miss out on, so please bring yourself to the Far, Far Range, share it's happiness and maybe even it's tears, or fear if we're talking about Tarr Slimes.
This game is worth it. You never truly lose any of that 20 dollars. Never. You earn it all back in beautiful story, well-made graphics, and fun gameplay that you could play for hours without getting bored.

Enjoy it, because I sure did.

The first time someone described Slime Rancher to me, my response was, "That sounds stupid." He spent a few more minutes convincing me, though, and I agreed to check PSN for the game. Sony had just rolled out the Extra and Premium tiers of their PS+ program, so I gave the game a try since it was free. A month later, I had the platinum trophy.

Due to life circumstances, I've been shifting a lot of my gaming activity back to Steam this year. I've been downloading old games I used to play (Puzzle Pirates? Memoir '44 Online? Blasts from the past!), resetting passwords for old accounts, and keeping an eye on game series I know I enjoy to grab on sale (Yakuza). I was more interested in buying Slime Rancher 2 than the original because of my platinum trophy, but I happened to catch the game on sale for a great price. I had plenty of funds in my Steam wallet, so I grabbed it. A month later, I've 100% completed the game again. I never finished all 57 achievements on the PlayStation 4 version (I believe there are only 33 trophies or so), so I've been very focused on finishing the achievements that I didn't unlock in my previous playthrough.

Simply put: this game is fun. The visuals are cute, colorful and stunning. Transitioning from the Dry Reef to Indigo Quarry, from Moss Blanket, to Ancient Ruins is beautiful, as each area has its own distinct feeling through artwork. I doubt this is the case, but some of the graphics seem almost hand-drawn and painted with water color, lending to the "cute and cuddly" aesthetic the game puts forth. The futuristic appeal is also driven home, by the ever present HUD with your vac pack, storage tanks, and easily accessed Slimepedia.

The music is charming and quirky, and it's very relaxing. I'm planning to purchase the soundtrack at a later date, and I'm looking forward to Slime Rancher 2's soundtrack. Again, each area has its own distinct feel, from the melancholy foreboding of the Glass Desert, to the jaunty almost sea shanty in the Far, Far Range. The music is rounded out by some stellar sound effects: each slime makes cute noises, each rarity has its own indicator, and teleporters and vac'd slimes just sound satisfying.

The controls are great. I played both the PS4 version and the Steam version with a PS4 controller, and the only issue I noticed was more of a Windows issue. I'd occasionally forget to plug in my controller before launching the game, so doing so would transfer the sound to the controller as if it were a headset. I'd have to minimize the game, go to setting and fix it, and then I'd have some weirdness with the menu afterward. Relaunching the game always fixed this, though.

Overall, I'm hoping to have the cashflow to purchase the sequel soon, and I'm excited to see what Monomi Park does with the series in the future.

slime rancher is, at its core, a tycoon-adventure game. if you don't like tycoons, you probably won't like this game either. collecting and selling ports, then upgrading your farm and your character are all integral to game progression. you're not sitting and waiting for plorts to spawn, though - usually you'll be out exploring the island and discovering more and gathering resources; while you're away, your slimes will eat the food you left in their corals, and you'll come back to plenty of plorts to sell. there's a couple minigame-type things, too - those are later in the game, though, and i don't know how to block things to avoid spoilers, so you'll have to take my word for it that they're alright. they help unlock some additional space, which can be really helpful if you want more farms n slimes n stuff.

[h1]Always remember to use your head, but let your heart do the thinkin' every now and again. It might surprise you.[/h1]

[h1]Introduction[/h1]
Slime Rancher is a superbly well-written exploration adventure of a young rancher who leaves Earth on a thousand-light-year journey to a strange land but develops a keen understanding of love, loss, life and death as she explores the land of Far, Far Range.

[table]
[tr]
    [th][b]🟩 Positives[/b][/th]
    [th][b]🟥 Negatives[/b][/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
    [td]🟩 An excellent story that captivates both heart and imagination.

🟩 Plenty of slimes and combinations to try out that your creativity will seem almost boundless.

🟩 A surprisingly large amount of things to do in the world coupled with a strong core gameplay mechanic.

🟩 The beautiful art style that masterfully counterparts a serene and soothing soundtrack.[/td]
    [td]🟥 The vacpack you use as your primary tool only has four available spaces. Travelling far distances can quickly become tedious when you run out of room. [/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[h1]Story[/h1]
You experience this journey as Beatrix LeBeau, who is a would-be slime rancher arriving on the Far, Far Range after a thousand-light-year voyage from Earth.

Throughout the game, as you progress across the many biomes available to explore, you start to receive mail from her love interest back on Earth, named Casey, who begins to tell you a story of their time together and what ultimately provoked Beatrix to leave.

To contrast the above obviously doomed-to-fail love story of Beatrix and Casey, you discover messages left behind by Hobson, the former owner of Far, Far Range, that tell you his tale of saying goodbye and how he fell in love and where that all eventually guided him.

Slime Rancher warmed my heart and provoked thoughts of a brighter tomorrow. These emotions have been harder and harder to experience in the past few months and to travel on this journey just when I needed it was simply sublime. The writing is impeccable, and the messages are meaningful, with pacing that ensures you are calm and relaxed the entire way through.

[h1]Gameplay Analysis[/h1]
[b]Exploration, but with a twist.[/b]
Slime Rancher isn't a simple farm game. At its very heart, it is built around exploration and discovery. Equipped with your all-purpose tool, the Vacpack, you will be required to bring back all sorts of things from all corners of the Range and use them to upgrade your farm. These can vary from slimes of all kinds to plorts (the reason you farm slimes at all) and even raw materials you will need to complete science experiments and construct gadgets.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2879323871

The vacpack only has four slots, but these slots are upgradeable and can store more of each item as you progress, but again only four items total, ever. Running out of space can be frustrating as there can be quite a considerable distance between the start and end of the game, and running out of room can become quite a time-consuming venture.

[b]Something strange in your neighbourhood.[/b]
The entire reason anyone would want to farm slimes is because of a thing called Plorts. Plorts are shiny shards that resemble the slime they come from that are generated when a slime has been fed food within its diet.
These can then get traded on the ranch for profit, and thus the life of a slime rancher begins.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2879324385

The further away from the ranch you travel, the more rare and valuable the slimes you discover will be, so travelling is more than just for exploration it will also help you actually progress the campaign and improve your ability to make money.

On top of the already significant abundance of slimes in the game, you have the opportunity to create hybrid slimes called Largos. These are formed when a regular slime of any type eats a plort of a different slime, it will then become the hybridisation of the plort it ate and its original form. This is a great way to farm multiple plort types in a single pen.

[b]A farmer's life for me.[/b]
Living on Far, Far Range is more than just exploration and farming slimes, it is about science, experimentation and creativity. Almost every facet of the farm is amendable, which allows you to choose where you place your crops, and pens are entirely up to you. You can make your farm as pretty as a picture or as efficient as a factory floor. The choice is entirely your own.

This is further progressive by unlocking different inventions through scientific discovery once you open the lab on the ranch. You quickly begin to utilise your materials in new and interesting ways and improve your quality of life immeasurably through the use of gadgets that you can place across your farm.

[h1]Audio and Visual[/h1]
Slime Rancher did not just captivate me with its incredible storyline and charming gameplay. It resonated through my entire being with its stunning art style that seemed to only deepen in complexity as the story drove onward. With every new awakening of the plot, the world would change to encompass it.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2879323812

This is entirely true of the soundtrack, as it evolves in perfect symbiosis with the story and biome transition. How the music plays with your emotions and unfurls upon the new realms of exploration is simply magical. Unfortunately, the animation sounds and overall atmospheric audio lacks any diversity.

[h1]PC Performance and Specifications[/h1]
I did not see my framerate dip below 60 FPS for the whole campaign with settings as high as they go at 2560 x 1440 resolution.
RAM: 32GB (Under Load Usage: 33%)
CPU: i9 10900KA 3.70GHz (Under Load Usage: 19.7%)
GPU: MSI Ventus RTX 3080 (Under Load Usage: 41%)

[h1]Final Thoughts - Excellent[/h1]
[url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2529084785]Review chart here.[/url]
A near-perfect score. This game absolutely blew me away beyond expectation and beyond reason. This game is more than just a game. It is a genuine experience that has changed the way I see lots of things in my life, and I sincerely hope I can hold onto this feeling for as long as I can. Slime Rancher is a must-play experience regardless of price.

The slimes are cute

Slime Rancher is an adorable and engaging game that's perfect for anyone who loves cute and colourful games. The game places you in the shoes of a rancher who must collect, raise and take care of various colourful slimes.

One of the best things about the game is the variety of slimes available to collect and interact with, each with their own unique characteristics. The game is also supplemented with plenty of challenges and missions that keeps the game interesting and engaging.

The game's graphics are simple, with a magical aesthetic that is both immersive and enchanting. The game's design and animation are top-notch and will captivate anyone who loves visually stunning games.

Another great aspect of Slime Rancher is the open-world aspect of the game. The game is expansive, and offers players a lot of freedom and flexibility to explore, experiment, and ultimately create their custom ranches, which adds an element of creativity to the gameplay.

The game's soundtrack is also worth mentioning as it is perfectly suited to the game's whimsical and engaging atmosphere. The game's background music, coupled with its graphics and fun gameplay, creates an enjoyable experience.

In conclusion, Slime Rancher is a fun and engaging game that is perfect for anyone who loves cute and colourful worlds and open-world exploration.
