[H1]So what's it about?[/H1]
You are a farmer on an alien planet at the Far, Far Range growing slimes - their produce is valuable so if you take good care of them, you earn a lot of money. You can then use that to upgrade your farm, getting better slimes and earning more valuable resources. It's a simple game loop similar to the countless other farming games. The difference is that it's in 3d and you can cross breed your slimes to earn even more money (but if you push too hard the slime becomes a monster so you want to avoid that). 

Now every slime has a food category is OK (vegetables, fruit, meat) but there is also a particular food for most slimes that they really like. If you feed them this, they give even more produce. You can expand your farm and soon after you need to do this, because the more of the same resource you sell on the market the less you get returned. It's nothing too complicated (not like Satisfactory or Factoria etc.) and at first it gives a nice challenge.

[H1]The good[/H1]
It's super cute and the initial gameplay loop is addictive. The level design is good with enough distinctive features that you will recognize quickly where you are. I hardly had to use the map. 

At the start it's a nice chill experience - it's one of those games that if you need to wind down it's there for you. 

I like that you can cross breed the slimes into newer ones. 

[H1]The not so good[/H1]
I did not finish Slime Rancher (at least I did not make it to the credits because there is no real ending). After the honeymoon period wears off (the phase of discovery what each slime can do and what upgrades there are and exploring the five areas): the game transforms into a tedious grind. 

You build single use machine with a chance to get rare resources of which you need many to get the next machine. All the while your farm has expanded to the point that half of the day is spend keeping your slimes fed. There are some mini quests that all need just resources so they give more resources. 

You are punished for willing to produce a lot as there are hard limits on the amount of machinery you can have at any time and they only produce items after 12 minutes (real life time). It is a mechanism that many mobile games use. There is no explanation why you can only use six machines. I wish we could automate all the things but it would mean that at one point the game or the farm would take care of itself and you discover that there is not so much endgame.

At that point I was pondering: am I still having fun? And I wasn't: the machines were just temporary things and then I had to rebuild over and over again: finding the resources, putting them in the refinery, getting the machine, placing it, run it for 12 minutes only to discover I didn't get the rare material I needed and then realising I had to go through this loop again. 

[SPOILER]To enter new areas wasn't particular fun: just find the big slime, figure out the favourite food and give 25 - 50 of those: more grinding. [/SPOILER]

The graphics are pretty basic - it's OK though as the gameplay and the cuteness factor works really well though.

The music is forgettable. 

I wish we could click away the permanent message that Slime Rancher 2 is out. I understand the devs are excited, but I don't need to see it permanently on the main menu.

[H1]Bug and glitches[/H1]
I experience one glitch where the tutorial to the laboratory would not disappear for 20 minutes covering 25% of the screen.

[H1]The DLCs[/H1]
The DLCs are mostly cosmetics - some are for free. They are not game changing and not essential: more meant to support the developer. They look cool and I can recommend them.

[H1]Summary[/H1]
Slime Rancher starts strong and the cuteness factor is its selling point. When this wears off, you realise that to keep you longer in the game you will need to grind a lot. The rewards to expand, to discover new things and to improve are limited. 

I know it’s a completely different genre but I felt like when I entered mid game Elite: Dangerous. There is no real progress it takes your time to not achieve much if anything at all. The way how you harvest on day 1 will be the same on day 100. There is some automation but even after that there is a lot of micromanagements. And to get to automation you have to do more grinding. 

Despite being super cute I cannot recommend Slime Rancher if you plan to spend more than a couple of hours on it.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I played this game for 5 hours and then a year later came back to it and then played more in the following week than I had in the previous year of having it.

For me "Metroidvania" basically means spending all your time looking for the fun challenges as you deal with the least fun challenge of all: getting lost, over and over in an unfamiliar place.

This game probably isn't technically what an expert would class as a Metroidvania but it does give you a particular relationship with a location and a landscape: it rewards exploration in which certain resources are immediately abundant but more covetable ones are naturally more scarce. You have places you can explore but it's never challenging to get back home (thank goodness) as you venture out little by little from your central hub. In this game you don't have to *grind* you just have to persevere and then one accumulation of wealth enables you to work more efficiently as you exponentially eliminate that grunt work. The grunt work is part of it though, as your upgrades give you incrementally increasing mastery of the landscape until you're literally soaring above it. It's an empowering experience.

It's not really about the slimes; it's about the vacuum pack. Yes, principally this is a farming simulator but with a dynamism as you whisk up those little guys (or any other item), it's as fun as it looks in the trailer.

Aesthetically adorable as you find new slimes in new locations, there is a darker layer beneath the surface; both the pathos of individuals searching the life they think is for them and also the sheer brutality of agriculture. They don't beat you over head with it but you have the choice of whether you kill or indeed run the farm vegan. I'm not a vegetarian but I liked doing what it took to not have to kill those chickens because I cannot taste them from where I'm sitting. Also remember that you are literally doing all of this for excrement. They look like jewels but that's part of the fun.

Though it can feel like something of a slog at times (you get into a routine of farming and think "is there anything more?"), I am not saying this doesn't need a few peeks at a walk through. But once I had laid just a basic foundation I was itching daily to apply my plans to run my farm as I wanted.

It is a game of exploration, resource management and physicality as you time your jumps over large distances and engage in combat against tarrs and ferals.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

6 tablespoons unsalted butter

1/2 cup white sugar

1/2 cup brown sugar

1/4 cup water

1/4 teaspoon cinnamon

1 pinch salt

5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced

1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).

Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.

Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.

Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.

Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.

Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

I love this game, you go at your own pace, its pretty open world, lots of areas to explore, and a wide variety of things for you to do. Early game it can be pretty slow, but if you know what your doing you can progress fairly quick. I like the different minigames and the areas the minigames eventually unlock. I do wish there was more to do after you pretty much complete everything, personally I've unlocked all the minigame areas, completed the slimepedia, and explored everywhere. I am excited to eventually get slime rancher 2 and play that but for now I have this. Its a relaxing game with cute slimes and lots to do, but once you do everything there really isn't much to do other than just grind plorts or make a new save file. All in all I give it a 8.8/10
